Posts.Title: Doc found lumps waiting for test

Posts.Content: Hope you have great plans for turkey day.  We are going to Carolyn's later today.  I have rolls to bake yet and a pie shell to fill with Butterscotch that I heard Carolyn's really wants.  Erica is making other pies.  I fixed a small turkey last night for the two of us so I could make gluten free stuffing and gravy.  Today we can carry that for Chuck.
Posts.Title: Happy Thanksgiving to All

Posts.Content: Sure there is all kinds of family history information relating to breast cancer. There is a board just for BRCA genetic discussion. Too early in the morning and my old brain is not connecting well enough to remember the address. It was begun by a lovely lady, Sue in Florida. She has done much work and helped with various groups studying and meeting to discuss family genes. OK It finally came to me the group is called FORCE. I am sure if you google FORCE you will find it. Not only family history of breast cancer figures in but also other related cancers in a family group. Rather than give you any misinformation, I will simply say that there is a Jewish group where the BRCA is very prevalent. I don't think there is any contagious classification for breast cancer. Calcification clusters can pinpoint breast cancer, so be sure to have mammos!!!! Hope all goes well! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: family genes- is there such as thing as a "Cancer Cluster"?

Posts.Content: The report does not sound too frightening but if it is worrisome to you, I would certainly look for a second opinion for sure. Are you near a big city where you might find breast specialists? Maybe you are near one of us and we could help. I am in the Fort Worth Area, Jo-Ann is in the Dallas area. We can cover some areas in OH, NJ, VA, SD, WA, CA..... and on. So if you need help there, just say so. Otherwise there is always the internet. If it is working??? I am rolling my eyes because I have satellite and for some reason there is no connection this morning and during the night, so I am on my slow dial up service I still keep just for this reason. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Got my report....

Posts.Content:
Thanks, I appreciate all thoughts and ideas. I did suggest to Carolyn that she would feel better, but she was worried about
 what it would cost................. They have insurance but it is not the greatest. She doesn't say much about
 what they had to pay for some of the tests, I think I heard $750 for the bone marrow test. She needs to get going on her SS Disability, that may help out with some costs. I think. I will let you know what she tells me after the meeting with the dr on Monday. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Hi, MK...

Posts.Content:
Oh great, call me on a stinken little letter. Vic is right you are lucky to be able to think at all, let alone think clearly. Whatever! LOL can't use ACRONYMS in Scrabble anyway!
Now let me tell you more about
 last week. You know we have been trying to sell our old house. We signed a contract in Nov for closing by Dec 21st requested by buyer. Just before that date we learned the buyer was in the middle of getting a divorce and the lender wanted her parents in on the contract. No problem closing would be before the end of the year. Well every week something happened putting it off, I could write a book. So back to last week. I am lying in the hospital bed and DH calls that there was a phone message from the title company. I called and it was a new title company, getting info again for the closing. The lady said she could come to the hospital for closing, no problem there. The next day which was Friday our Realtor called and said, "you are not going to believe this, but...." They buyer had a nervous breakdown and it caused a stroke, she is in the same hospital. Well, I guess that ends that saga, poor woman is only in her 40's life has not been great to her, evidently. 
Then on Saturday when I got back from my CT scan DH says to me, "Want another shocker?" He handed me the paper with a big article about
 our former next door neighbor. He had been hit by a car and died. He was 60, a lawyer and former judge with a second wife and a darling little daughter. Remember all the times we have said we could be hit by a car tomorrow? It happens. It is very upsetting to me that the little girl who spent a lot of time with her daddy won't have him anymore.
Today begins a new week, whatever has taken place in the past couple seems to be clearing. My blood sugar is only 88 this morning!!!!!! It hasn't been that low in a couple years. I am going to rest for a few days and try to keep it that way.
Hugs MK

Posts.Title: MK Called from Hospital

Posts.Content: I just do not understand why doctors are so hesitant to get the biopsy done right away instead of waiting six months. A biopsy is no big deal. Waiting six months could be if they made the wrong decision. Yes, you can tell a lot by the picture of the lump but you can not be absolutely certain. I would push for a biopsy or at least get my records and get a second opinion preferably by a breast specialist. I agree with Gail wholeheartedly. I am not wanting to frighten you, but waiting six months would be more stressful to me than being sure right now. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: 26 years old...unsure of what may brings

Posts.Content:
You have really hit the nail on the head about
 her healing problems. Smoking is a real problem, especially in the quantity you describe. And all that alcohol ???? Absolutely rest and good healthy food are important to healing, also. As to the link between breast cancer and smoking, I quit the day I got my diagnosis. Why in the world would I even jeopardize any part of my body with cigarettes when they are a proven cancer factor, even if no one has found a link to breast cancer. Breast cancer is related to other cancers which are related to smoking, so how would you know? 
Happy holidays to you, too. I saw a Scrabble puzzle book on Amazon that looks like fun. Have you ever tried one?
Hugs MK

Have a Merry Christmas and try to put it out of your mind for a couple of months. Yeah, I know easier said than done. But keep busy reading or watching movies or whatever makes you happy and resting.

Posts.Title: Met w/ the Surgeon

Posts.Content:
I have been having pain in my abdomen for over a week, getting increasingly worse.  Yesterday I spent all day at the doctor's and hospital having tests.   There is something going on in the colon.  I had a colonoscopy about
 two months ago which was clear.  Anyhow, I have no details just the fact that my doctor sent the surgeon the CT scan report and they will be discussing the situation and letting me know what needs to be done.  Meanwhile I am lying down 95% of the time because that is the best way to lessen the pain.  Jo-Ann is having problems with her new computer, soon as she gets it running she can post and let you know what is going on if I can't.  Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Looks like I am going to have more surgery.

Posts.Content: I tried to call her last night and got no answer, which worried me some. But then she sometimes goes to bed early. I'll try to call today and let you know what is going on if she doesn't. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Jo-Ann..what happened yesterday ?

Posts.Content:
That was a wonderful post Lauri, no one could have said it better. Thank you for expressing your thoughts so well for all of us.
I will never forget the day Mitchell died. For some reason I decided to call Jo-Ann that morning. I had never talked to her. When I called her son answered the phone and there seemed to be an urgency in his voice when he told me she couldn't come to the phone and he would have her call me later. When we talked later of course I was shocked at what had happened. Within a day or two I drove to Garland to meet her. That was just two weeks before I had surgery which changed my life so drastically. We have been friends ever since. She is supposed to be coming this weekend for a visit. However, she was not feeling so well when I talked to her last. Hope you are feeling better Jo-Ann. 
Hugs MK+
Posts.Title: Another year has gone by....

Posts.Content:
Amen and Amen! It is soo good to see and hear from you. Please don't stay away so long. I know life is busy and especially with grandchildren we want to spend all the time we can with them. I have a third great grandchild on the way, HE will be born in November. Are either of you adding to your family? 
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Luci & Lauri.....

Posts.Content:
Hi next step and welcome. You sound great! That is encouraging to newbies who may have questions about
 IBC. We have a member here who had IBC and is doing fine, too. She doesn't post real often but I always hope when I see IBC that she will see the post and respond. Keep doing well! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Does Inflammatory Breast Cancer Hurt?

Posts.Content:
By all means, see a specialist. It may be nothing, but then again it could be something and if it is in a lymph node then it could be moving in the lymphatic system. Does your doctor not consult with other doctors? In my experience, my doctors called specialists to ask their advice and help right while I was in the office. My plastic surgeon who is one of the best in the city called infectious disease dr when I had a bad infection, a trauma specialist to ask about
 an IV, a radiologist to help with treatments and on and on. I don't understand why doctors just want to wait and see. We haven't run this question through lately, but you can always ask the doctor, if a male, "Is this what you would want for your wife or daughter? Wait six months and check again?" I think not. But then again 6 mm is really very small. I don't know how they could see a shape of a kidney that small, unless it was magnified quite a bit. I really would rather know than wait, anyhow. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: New Info On My Situation

Posts.Content: Yeah I am wondering why they don't just do the lumpectomy, too. Maybe because of your other health problems they don't want to give you anesthesia unnecessarily? I feel badly that you are going through all this, and hope that soon you will have some answers. Life is never fair, is it? Hugs MK
Posts.Title: core biopsy

Posts.Content: Thanks Becky for posting for me! Thanks to all for the prayers and get well wishes. I came home this afternoon and am trying to get mail and computer stuff somewhat caught up before lying down. I feel much better. All the doctors could come up with was a possible pylonephritis. I really hurt but there was not a lot of infection, etc. in the tests run. The CT scan showed inflamatory tissue but again it was not an obvious differentiation. I will still be on antibiotics at home this week and I intend to rest. My blood sugar and blood pressure had been high for a couple of weeks and now they are down to very normal numbers for diabetes. So maybe every so often I just need a little cleansning? The surgeon said I should absolutely never have surgery unless gangrene or something life threatening set in because with no muscles behind the outer skin no sutures would ever hold and I would just pull apart. I've known that I can not waste time getting antibiotics or treatment if anything is strange. Sorry we didn't have time to arrange the PCA. The nurses I had were great and really fun. They would have loved seeing you all "in the pink". As a matter of fact I had a room mate for part of a day who has Altzheimer's. They had a monitor on her that played a little tune when she got up. I told the nurse it would drive me crazy soon because it was an awful do do do do do tune. She laughed and started dancing around the room singing it and told me all I needed to do was get in the groove and dance. They were a really fun group! I did not eat any green jello!!!! Thanks again for your love and prayers, MK
Posts.Title: MK Called from Hospital

Posts.Content:
Yes, it is possible for the two different kinds of cancer. One of our group had a different cancer in her second breast about
 eight years after the first. She is one who had a double mastectomy and did not have reconstruction. She is about
 your wife's age, too. I would say in the mid 50s and later perhaps it is easier to live without reconstruction. More carefree. When dressed up you can wear prosthesis and look feminine, but otherwise can do what you want and feel as comfortable as you want. Reconstruction is much harder surgery than mastectomy surgery. Take care and tell your wife we all send our best wishes. Mary K.
Posts.Title: need advice Please

Posts.Content:
"One of my hardest parts of my job is to console the family members who have lost their life." 
I had trouble typing this one, trying to correct it as I typed. LOL What a difference a few words changed makes!
One of the hardest parts of my job is to console the family members who have lost loved ones.
MK
Posts.Title: Lauri Just for you!!

Posts.Content:
Thanks again for your concern!!!! I am feeling better for sure! It is unbelievable what a good dose of antibiotics did for me! My blood sugar is absolutely great for the first time in months and months! My blood pressure is also great. Guess I did need a rest at the spa! Sure, Lori, it is a spa alright when they walk in at 6 am flip on the overhead light and say "I am here to get some blood!!!!" I am still in pain, but that will always be. I just need to learn to lie more than sit and stand. 
about
 Carolyn, she has blood work weekly and it waivers back and forth in the low range. When the hemoglobin gets below 8 I guess she will have to have that blood transfusion but it stays between 8 and 8.4. She did tell me her platelet count is getting lower, tho. I am not sure what that means but I can't feel very good about
 it. 
She called me yesterday to check on me and to see if the very, very high winds were causing fires around here. They were all over north TX yesterday, gusts of 53 mph. One community close to where we used to live lost 14 homes. There was a fire blocking the road on the way Carolyn's house causing the school bus to detour and it took Natalie an extra hour to get home. She sounded really stressed and worried about
 fires. 
We put in a very rough night last night. Missy, my 14 yr old dog, was really sick. I actually thought she had a stroke and was dying in my arms when she heaved and threw up all over me. She did that a couple more times, and finally it looked like she was going to feel better. She has not gotten up to go outside yet this morning but she has stirred and is sleeping on her pillow beneath me under the computer desk. I know it is only a matter of time with her, but I think she will be ok for now. 
Thanks again for asking, you girls take care, too.
love u, MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> Missy  my 14 yr old dog  was really

Posts.Title: MK, how are you feeling?

Posts.Content:
Today's quote:
"Our enemies are innovative and resourceful, and so are we. They never stop thinking about
 new ways to harm our country and our people, and neither do we."
Isn't that the truth? MK
Posts.Title: Lauri Just for you!!

Posts.Content:
I love how they make it sound so "favorable" like it is no big concern when we know darn well at this point in her diagnosis no one can tell how favorable it is. How many from our group had a favorable diagnosis to have a recurrence eight years or more later? We thought Carolyn's diagnosis was like mine. They were favorable but eleven years later I am showing NED and she is in a fight for her life after eight years. 
And what is going on with Elizabeth Edwards? I haven't been watching much TV and haven't seen her, but my sister in law said she had heard something about
 her mets and thought she was looking pretty ragged. She thought she heard something about
 bone marrow. Wasn't her initial prognosis good, too? 
Guess I am just getting more and more cynical about
 the news and all the "spin" for whatever reason. Sorry.
L&H MK
Posts.Title: Dorothy Hamill has breast cancer....

Posts.Content: Hi Sniper, I just took the time to catch up on this thread. I am glad to hear your wife had her surgery and is doing so well. I agree with your earlier statement that LA heat is miserable (like TX where I live) and to go braless would be so much more comfortable. I am sure you are taking good care of her and she appreciates it. Keep trying to talk her into coming to talk to us. MK
Posts.Title: need advice Please

Posts.Content:
Well maybe we can get the ball rolling here. I didn't get a leg lamp, nor have ever seen the Christmas Story totally. It was on at Carolyn's Christmas Day and I missed that part, but from your descript
ion I can imagine. One of my favorite presents is a calendar with daily sayings. Since I don't want to be politically incorrect, I will only say it has "isms" from a political figure who has never learned to talk in public, even after seven years in office. 
My husband got me a new computer chair with a high back and a mat for under it so it will roll on the carpeting. Since I spend most of my up time sitting here, it was something I really needed. My son got me a scanner for slides that you can put old slides into the computer. We have tons of them from when I was young and the kids were little, so soon as I get it hooked up and find that box of slides I will be busy. I am really looking forward to seeing them on the computer. We tried about
 fifteen years ago to video them from a screen but running a video and moving slides just didn't work real well, we upside down pictures, blurry pictures and the order did not turn out like I thought I had it laid out.
I got some clothes, perfume, pictures, CDs, and it was a great Christmas. 
Happy New Year to you all, MK
Posts.Title: What was your best Christmas gift this year???

Posts.Content:
Yes we have missed your smiling face and a lot of others. Where is everyone? I know getting ready for Christmas is a chore and takes a lot of time. I hope now that the holidays are about
 over, everyone will come back and check in with us. I have to get my AIM set up on the new computer, I can't even see when some of my friends are on line. And I need to get Literati set up so I can play with Libby and Becky once in awhile. Jo-Ann has had all her family with her over the holidays so I haven't heard from her. I did get to see everyone of my children, grandchildren and great grandchildren in December. You can't beat that!
I'm sorry your work has turned so ugly. That's the way they seem to be doing things in government these days, forget the kids, send the money to fight in Iraq. We had a pretty good health program in TX for kids with no insurance, but that was cut to pieces too for lack of funding. Meanwhile our most precious assets are being neglected. Kids can't help it they are born with problems or problem parents. I know you are doing the best you can with the time you have. Just don't let it wear you out. 
Love and hugs back to you,
MK
Posts.Title: After Christmas update...pure fluff

Posts.Content:
Ditto! A Happy New Year to all! I will probably be sound asleep with my two fur babies as the new year rolls in. They hardly let me out of sight anymore and I am so thankful for the love and comfort they provide.
Hugs and love to all,
MK
Posts.Title: Happy Happy New Year!

Posts.Content:
Yes that is true here also. I think it might be a nationwide thing. My brother donates regularly in WV and he said he could transfer credit to her. I told her that. Her father has the same type blood and has offered to give her his blood if they will let him. I am still waiting to hear about
 her dr visit today. She told Erica she expects her blood count to be up today since she feels so much better than she did. She is drinking a glass of Blackberry wine a day to help her blood count because she learned somewhere it is good for anemia. Her appointment was at 1:30 and it is now almost 3:30. Maybe the dr told her to get to the hospital and get that transfusion???? Will post later when I know something.
We have also been waiting all day for the call to come and sign papers for the closing of our house and that call has never come, either. Funny how when you expect calls the phone never rings......... all day not one call. I called Erica to see if she had heard anything.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Hi, MK...

Posts.Content:
Thanks Luci, for all the kind words and thoughts. It is great to see you here posting, today. I think of you often, too. I know you are enjoying your grandchildren as I am my great grandchildren. Somehow we just don't post as often as we once did. We have lost far too many dear friends. Now the possibility is looming that I am going to see my own daughter fight the great battle so many have fought and are still fighting. Yesterday she helped the "boys" in the family lay some of that new hardwood flooring, they tried to keep her on easy jobs. LOL. She is quite the character. Tomorrow she will learn more about
 her situation. She says the doctor had some more smears done with the bone marrow to determine what course might be best.
I haven't posted a lot about
 Carolyn, she had swollen lymph nodes in her neck in February and the biopsy showed BC had spread. She has been hurting in her back and hips for a long time. A bone scan showed hot spots, which she informed me did not mean breast cancer, it could be arthritis, too because scans don't show the difference. Yeah right. She has been on Aridea and Femara and kept telling us how they were working, yet we learned more lesions were seen in her bone scan before this last one, which did not show any new areas. Blood work showed she was anemic, so she was given a boost of medicine I had never heard of making her feel better, but one week later the hemoglobin had dropped another half point. She is in the severely anemic range, so that is why they wanted the blood transfusions. She insists she feels ok. Just tired. Then they did the bone marrow tests and found the BC cells which she still has not told me about
. She did tell Erica and so did her husband tell Erica. Erica is a real worrier, but it almost seems Carolyn is trying to keep me from being upset and worried. Like ten years of being associated with a breast cancer board hasn't prepared me for just about
 anything.
Tomorrow we also are supposed to close on the sale of our old house. One year it has taken to sell it and already the closing was moved ten days. We are hoping to get it closed on the last day of 2007 so it won't carry over into 2008 for taxes, etc. The woman who is buying is going through a divorce so the lender is insisting on her parents being on the mortgage until the divorce is finalized. 
So tomorrow is a big day. I hope things go exceptionally well to finish out 2007. And here's to a great 2008 for all of us.
Love and hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Hi, MK...

Posts.Content:
Oh Cathi, if there was only some way to stop all this disease!!!! God love you, you have been through so much. 
I am seeing a few years into the future and Carolyn going through it all, too. She's still refusing to let us do things for her. Erica offered to do her Christmas shopping and help her wrap, etc. It would help her and us if she would just let us do something. I hope you have lots of help and accept it. 
There is nothing we can do physically for you girls to help the pain or stop what is going on in your bodies. I would gladly give my body to any of the younger women if it could be arranged. Not that I don't enjoy life, but I have lived to see my children grown and successful, to see them have wonderful children like they were. And now the great grandchildren, they are the most precious babies. 
Bless you dear friend, I hope you find some comfort from your pain in the holiday season and your wonderful family surrounds you with love. I know your friends from Healingwell and other hood over the years love you very much. 
Big Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Birthday Thanks & update

Posts.Content: Oh Mel, it always happens!!! Always the weekend to wait through. Actually the techs are not to tell you anything, the radiologist will read your tests and send the report to your doctor who will tell you the results. That always takes a day or two. I have had the radiologist talk to me an give me results but only a couple of times. The first was when he was sure I had breast cancer and he advised me to make sure my doctor took action asap. The other times were when I went to a special breast clinic for mammograms, the Dr made sure to give results to breast cancer patients right away to alleviate the worry. His clinic closed down because insurance and medicare payments did not cover the costs adequately. That was a real shame because it was the best place I ever went to have a mammogram and I have had plenty over the last 30 years. Let us know what you find out. We will keep you in our prayers and thoughts over the weekend. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: lack of results?

Posts.Content:
Just be there to let her talk if she will, knowing you are fully supportive of her choices. If she is having trouble making choices let her talk them out with you. You didn't mention a father or husband, so I am assuming you might be her main male support. Let her know you love her and are there.
As for luck, cancer is never good luck or bad. You deal with what you need to with the best advice you can draw on. As always early detection is best. Some cancers are more aggressive than others, and need to be treated aggressively. All the women I have met through cyberspace have stood up to the challenge and fought their battles in the most unbelieveable ways. Some have lost their battles, of course, but they were true heros til the end. Many of this group have been around for over nine years together. 
Give your mom A HUG from us, MK
Posts.Title: Support From A Son

Posts.Content:
I sure hope by now you have some results. Most of my mammograms and sonograms have been done at Harris Hospital NW in Azle which is where I lived before moving to Bowie. That is also where I had my mastectomy. It is a small hospital, a part of the Harris Hospital system in Fort Worth. I have always gotten good care and have not had to wait long for results of tests. Where are you in Texas? Probably in the other direction from FW I bet! Jo-Ann is north of Dallas, but she is having some health issues right now with blood sugar especially. 
Take care and let us know.
Mary K.
Posts.Title: lack of results?

Posts.Content: Here is a quote from Friday I thought you might appreciate.
Posts.Title: Lauri Just for you!!

Posts.Content:
Thanks for your input Jen, I know about
 general anemia. My husband was diagnosed with celiac disease last February which was found by anemia and then an upper GI scope with biopsy. I suggested Carolyn tell her onc about
 the celiac because it is genetic, but she didn't because she understood one of the meds she takes is a problem for blood cells and besides she said, "If I had celiac disease I would have had it all my life not just now." I reminded her that her father was just diagnosed and it was because he became very anemic last year all of a sudden. I just wasn't sure what they were looking for with the bone marrow test. I know leukemia is related to bone marrow. I know there are blood cancers that could be related, but does mets ever show up in bone marrow? We will probably know more in a week or two. Her test is next Tuesday. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Need help to understand about daughter's test.

Posts.Content: Carolyn had her bone marrow test yesterday.  Meanwhile her blood count has dropped significantly again.  They wanted to give her a blood transfusion yesterday but she asked to wait until the bone marrow tests come back. See what I mean she is such a STROUP stubborn as they come.  I still need to pull out her father's blood tests from his anemic problem to compare numbers.
Posts.Title: Update on Carolyn and we're back from a wonderful weekend!!!

Posts.Content: A month ago Carolyn's blood work showed anemia.  I am not sure what was done at that time, but she was to have another blood test this month when she went for her Aredia infusion.  It showed her red cells count was even lower, so they are going to do a bone marrow test next week.  What are they looking for?  Does anyone know?  She says one of her medicines is supposed to cause problems with blood count, but the meds seem to be working as far as the bone scan shows etc. They gave her a shot of something that sounds like angen aran esp which meanss nothing to me.
Posts.Title: Need help to understand about daughter's test.

Posts.Content: Wow this is a first! Singapore!!!! We have had New Zealand, and UK women before but never Singapore! Maybe that is why you are getting such great care! And it does sound great to me. We will be waiting to hear on the 17th. Meanwhile if you have any questions we are here. Hugs Mary K.
Posts.Title: 26 years old...unsure of what may brings

Posts.Content:
I was going to mention Susan's problem, too. The biggest problem with her was her first doctor treated her exactly the opposite of how the second doctor diagnosis indicated. He was just about
 to get her on the right track when she passed away. Another lesson in life illnesses, if problems don't get better maybe a second opinion might be in order. She originally was living in OK and moved to GA, and the dr in Atlanta, GA was the one who said she had been treated contrary to indications. What a terrible loss that could have been prevented so easily. So Bern, please get to a doctor and find the best one you can. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Questions on heart problems after chemo

Posts.Content:
I think I have heard about
 lymphedema in other parts of the body besides the arm, more especially the trunk of the body. Other than that I have no idea why one foot would be larger except for edema just plain swelling from circulatory problems. I think this is one for the doctor to look at. How is your ankle and your calf? Are they swollen and tight? Can you leave fingerprints when you press on them? Check it out so when you call for a doctor's appointment you can tell them. Let us know what you find out. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: just a strange question

Posts.Content:
Thank you for your nice message. I'm so sorry about
 your aunt. Breast cancer is an ugly disease for sure, as are all the cancer diseases. We do have a wonderful group of women here who have lived through various stages and degrees of the disease and are fighting every day. Everyone hopes for a cure asap. Just be sure to preach awareness and to do self exams, have annual checkups and annual mammograms!! Early detection is a good thing! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Hello Ladies, just visiting

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday Becky. I hope you had a wonderful party. I would have called and sung Happy Birthday earlier but I am afraid my voice is getting weaker as I tire. LOL. I am having some wonderful soup and grilled cheese for supper so I will think of you as I "party" at home. Love MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday, Becky!

Posts.Content: She is home from the hospital. Her sugar has been regulated with a new insulin that is very fast acting, but the balance between it and food, as I understand, is quite close. It sounds like it will work for her. Her son took her a Mac laptop that she is able to use to get on line. Her computer is still down. She told me she would post, but as you see she hasn't. That is why I haven't updated, I thought I would let her tell you. She is still not well, but much better and is awaiting test results. She has doctor's appointments for the next three weeks, but she is not supposed to drive. If she doesn't post I will try to keep you updated. I got an email over the weekend, but have not talked to her since Friday. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Any updates on Jo-Ann??

Posts.Content:
Yes we know the bone scan shows spots, but as Carolyn keeps telling me, it could be arthritis. All the bone scan shows are hot spots. So you see she does tend to try to make me not worry. Remember, too, she works way too hard and says that Lance Armstrong beat cancer by working. I just don't remember others here with bone mets having bone marrow tests. Cathi, are you reading? Have you had bone marrow tests? 
Hugs to all,
MK
Posts.Title: Need help to understand about daughter's test.

Posts.Content:
I know of nothing that would make the areola change colors that has to do with breast cancer. Pregnancy changes the color. So perhaps it may have something to do with hormones. I really don't think it is anything to worry about
, but mention it to the dr next time you go.
Posts.Title: color change concerning areola

Posts.Content: I just wanted to add a note that Missy is ok. She was strange for a few days, but now she is acting normal again. As normal as an old dog acts. Sleeping most of the time. My blood sugar continues to be good. I am checking in with my regular dr today. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: MK, how are you feeling?

Posts.Content: OKaaaaaayyyyyy!!!! Doesn't it make you feel better when a doctor takes you seriously? I think if we don't look sick, tired and are dragging sometimes doctors tend to think you are not having any real problems. They make you feel like a wuss if you complain. My daughter that has not been diagnosed with BC goes to a specialist who keeps a close eye on her. She recently had a sonogram of her ovaries and uterus to check for cancer there because she took fertility drugs 18 years ago and with the breast cancer history the doctors want to be really thorough. So specialists do look at you with a different perspective and I think you will be happy seeing her and hearing her viewpoint. Keep us posted. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Scheduled For Ultrasound

Posts.Content:
Hi I fixed your duplication!! I haven't had any experience with a port, but I had a PICC line off and on for about
 a year. Jo-Ann posted not long ago about
 having her port removed after several years. You Might want to find that post and read it. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Does anyone here have an implanted Port??

Posts.Content:
Last night's report was that he is eating, the hospital food is delicious. Hmmm no green jello? They are filling him with IV liquids and antibiotics, but he still had a temp of 101.6 yesterday afternoon with all of that. Still chillin' and sweating. Urinalysis was clear. Waiting yet for blood results. He sees a rheumatologist for some long named condition I know little about
 so they are communicating with him to see if it might be something he can suggest. I told Stella over a week ago to call his other doctors offices and explain his situation and see if they could help. He also sees a kidney doctor on a regular basis. Will report in again. This is really crazy how sick he is. Jo-Ann said it sounds a lot like her problems this summer. Thanks for your prayers, MK
Posts.Title: Some prayers for a friend and a need to vent.............

Posts.Content:
I answered this earlier today. I must have forgotten to hit submit. Getting old is scarier every day.
Thanks for the great Thanksgiving Day card, Jo-Ann! I know you bought it just for me because it matches my birthday card and we both loved that one, too. 
Congratulations to Officer Bates!!! Don't be scared, he will do well. No one will mess with anyone that big!!!!
Will be thinking of you on the 27th. I go for my diabetic eye exam on the 26th. Do we ever do anything but run to the drs and to labs for tests? LOL
Love MK
Posts.Title: Happy Thanksgiving to All

Posts.Content:
Gretchen, I did not have chemo, but have been around here long enough to know everyone reacts differently. They give anti- nausea drugs that work very effectively for some. My daughter went through chemo and I think she had what you are having. She did not have good insurance that paid much on drugs at the time, so she took as few as possible and did fine without too much nausea. Her main complaint was tiredness. She worked through the chemo. Hers was every three or four weeks, can't remember now. Things change all the time. I hope with your Chron's it is manageable. Like you needed something else in your life!!! Right?
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: chemo treatment

Posts.Content: LOL Love them all! I hope we created a few smiles today. MK
Posts.Title: Jo-Ann for you....A quote from my calendar for today.

Posts.Content: Sounds like old age, too. I have an email that takes you through a whole day of starting something and moving on to the next project without ever finishing a one. that's how my life is anymore. LOL Thanks for the chuckle. MK
Posts.Title: Just to give you all a chuckle

Posts.Content:
When she made the appointment did she tell them of the redness and the swelling? Something is wrong there for sure. I suggest she call back and tell them of her discomfort and see if she can get the appointment moved up. Tell her to be sure to give them all the details on the phone.
Sorry I didn't answer sooner, I thought this was about
 having radiation and since I never had it I felt I couldn't be of any help. Things have been a little slow lately and I noticed you were not answered so I decided to check and see if I could help. 
Hugs MK another Scrabblenut!!!
Posts.Title: Radiation after-effect?

Posts.Content: We were thinking of you, too, Cathi. I talked with Jo-Ann and she remembered that you were having chemo. Take care aand God Bless You. MK
Posts.Title: Dear Cathi...

Posts.Content: Sounds good, please report back and let us know what she found out. You never know it may be helpful to someone else. Have fun playing Scrabble. MK
Posts.Title: Radiation after-effect?

Posts.Content: Oh how I would love to see everyone, but there is no way. I can't get around as well as I used to. Trying to walk even the shortest distance hurts not only when I am walking but later I pay for it, too. Going to see my mother for a few days wears me out for at least a week more and I do nothing but visit. I hope you can all get together and have a great time, tho. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: A Gathering and you are invited

Posts.Content:
Anthi, I can't imagine getting all those phone calls from your mother! My mother is also 94 and has been in a home for the aged about
 15 months now. It is a big adjustment for them, that's for sure. But she will settle down and accept that she is where she needs to be. They are fed three square meals a day and kept clean. If they will participate there are activites to keep them occupied, too. There is no way I can care for my mother, and it sounds like you have more than enough on your plate, too. Talk to the people there and see if they can somehow stop all the phone calls. Or do something to shut off your phone, you can't stand all that stress. If her short term memory is bad, she probably doesn't remember making the call two minutes ago. When I talk to my mother on the phone she tells me the same thing about
 three or four times with no idea she just finished the very same sentence. So don't feel like the phone calls are for real. My mother doesn't remember in the evening if she had any company or phone calls that day, she tells me she talked to no one, then I find out her sister was there and took her out to lunch. Do you have a brother or sister to help? Please feel free to email me if you need to talk about
 this situation off the board. I would even be glad to call you and talk if it would help. You don't need the stress in your life while you are fighting breast cancer. Hugs MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> My mother is also 94 and has been in a

Posts.Title: Update

Posts.Content: Lauri, a wheelchair is not the answer. I have an electric cart here at home, a walker with a seat, and I never even go down my hallway without pushing a tray table to lean on. The longer this goes on the more it hurts. I am now wearing four binders at a time and it still does not really help. I feel like I have a hundred pound kid hanging on my back at my waist pulling down as I drag them along. I move from chair to chair in my kitchen. I haven't been inside a mall since 2001. I have gone to an outlet mall twice with someone pushing me in a wheelchair, but when you get inside the stores there is not room to move around, so I usually sit parked near the door while everyone else shops. It is so much easier to just stay at home. I go to a concert where my grandson is playing, park in handicapped parking only to find when I get in the building I have to walk a long hallway to get to the auditorium. Carting the scooter around is a pain, the walker is a little easier, but then I still walk with it. When Jo-Ann and I drove to Louisville I was exhausted for over a week afterwards. No one in the medical profession seems to understand. My dr is hesitant to do an exam for fear of hurting me, and I keep telling her nothing hurts when I am touched, most of my abdomen is dead feeling. I need something to lift the hernia, but so far I have not found anything that does what I need and believe me I have looked on the internet and tried many different binders and abdominal lifts. I am looking at some full body things now that cost nearly $300 but I am not sure they will help, either. Do I want to spend that kind of money for naught? Sorry I am complaining so much, but it is so frustrating not to be able to do things I want so badly to do. But I keep telling myself that at least I am alive. Then there is Mother who tells me every night she has lived too long. And my daughter won't live long enough. Grrrr Hugs MK
Posts.Title: A Gathering and you are invited

Posts.Content:
I am really surprised she knows your phone number. My mother can't ever find her book where she has numbers and there is no way she can call. I doubt she ever learned the numbers because she has not called that much. I am usually the one who calls her. I programmed her phone about
 two years ago but she didn't understand then how to use it, now it would be impossible. My mother sits and plays Solitaire and does crosswords. It is surprising how much of the crosswords she gets done, too. I made a mistake and bought her pink cards just for fun only to learn that the suits were not different colors, everything was pink and white. I watched her play for awhile to see if she would recognize the shapes and put them together correctly when playing. For the most part she did, but she never mentioned how strange it was to have them all pink and white. I can only imagine how frightening it has to be to reach that stage in life. She realizes how confused she is sometimes and really clams up then. Anytime you need to vent please feel free to email me. Since you are across the pond I guess I can't call. LOL. I have a set amount phone bill with unlimited long distance, but that doesn't include out of the USA. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Update

Posts.Content:
I had to go to my other computer where I have Juno still connected and sure enough I found the email, too. I was brave and 
opened the window and all that was there was blue, a pretty aqua blue, not the blue screen of death as Jo-Ann calls it when the computer dies. I am running a Norton full scan now to make sure no virus is there. Right under that email from Connie's address was one sent a year ago from an old co-worker. I am sure I got the email last year from her, it was after we moved and I sent some pictures of the house. So something crazy was going on in space for sure.
Remember a few months after Peggy died I got an email from her. I called her mother and also talked to her son, trying to figure out if someone had used her computer and sent it by mistake. They both told me her computer had been turned off since she had died. I thought maybe someone who had had access to her computer and really knew their way around the computer world was playing mind games with me. But I never got an answer on that one, either.
It sure is strange and frightening. I think I will call Jo-Ann and see if she has any ideas.
Hugs to all, Mary K.
Posts.Title: A HEART SKIPPING E-MAIL

Posts.Content:
Hi Hipsy,
I didn't see any mention of your mom seeing her oncologist regularly but you mentioned she is having tests done next week. She should have been under care, even if as an annual thing for tests, etc. My daughter is fighting a recurrence that happened at eight years. She was not seeing her onc or even having annual mammograms at the time. It took us all by surprise. We know that breast cancer is now being treated more like an ongoing problem to be watched and kept under control somewhat like Diabetes. So if your mom has been to her doctor and is not discussing her situation with you, you need to talk with her and tell her you are very concerned and fearing the worst. I certainly understand your last comment, my daughter insists she is fine when I know that is not true. She is doing ok with her treatments, but certainly not fine.
Hope you all get good news next week.
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: New here..

Posts.Content: Holley, we are here to help in any way we can. Come here any time you want some company and let it out. What part of the country do you live in? It is possible one of us could even be near enough to meet you for lunch and visit in person. You can see pictures in the Roll call above, although it might be quite a search for them. My daughter and I both have breast cancer. Mine has been quiet for nearly 11 years. She recently had a recurrence but is doing well on the drugs and treatment prescribed. There are all ages of women here. I am the oldest at 68. We live in north central TX. Please feel free to come and talk. Hugs MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: I am the oldest at 68 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: 41 & Scared

Posts.Content:
Kathy I am sorry I meant to mention your CT scan problem. I am down to one vein on my good arm, too. It was used for CT scan and blood tests when I was admitted to the hospital. Then it blew and they needed to put the IV in again. The used the under part of my forearm. Now that is a tender place and also a pain to deal with the needle and the lines from it. Finding the vein made a huge black and blue mess!!!!! But when it all came out it healed faster than the usual black and blue spot does.
I think your doctor is wise to keep close tabs on you, even if your veins don't like it. 
Big hugs, MK
Posts.Title: HAPPY VALENTINES DAY

Posts.Content: Lori, I think it has something to do with Iodine in seafood and seaweed. Iodine or lack thereof affects the thyroid. My daughter, Chris, was diagnosed with Graves Disease a condition of a hyperactive thyroid. Usually thyroid problems including cancer are very treatable, but even so who wants and needs them, right? I hope all is well. My sil had thyroid cancer back in 68 and has not had any problems after removal of her thyroid. Keep us posted. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Thyroid nodule....

Posts.Content:
I understand from your post that you have read this is a common occurance. There is no need to "stop" it nor to worry about
 it. Your doctor has told you not to worry about
 it. If it helps any I will share that I had the same situation from only one breast. It happened until I was no longer able to bear children. I still have that breast, the one that didn't leak is gone. So my advice is to find something else to keep your mind busy and get on with a normal life. LOL. And here is my favorite line. "Don't worry until you know you have something to worry about
!!" Hugs MK
Posts.Title: My breasts are leaking!

Posts.Content:
I tell my daughter all the time that she should not do half the things she does, to ask someone else! Now, really, Kitty was there no one else to help move that piano? You know better than to move something like that. Gees--- It is time to let the younger folks do some things. I am getting really good at that. 
My computer is great, so fast and this huge screen is great! 
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Just checkin in

Posts.Content: Cathi, Thanks a lot for taking the energy and time to post to us. I know it is difficult for you, but we so much appreciate hearing from you. I'm praying the study works great for you. You are a true hero to all of us. My thoughts and prayers are with you. Love and Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Latest update...

Posts.Content: She called me this morning from Allen Presbyterian Hospital.  They admitted her immediately with a BP of 88/59, blood sugar over 500 and severely dehydrated.  She has UT infection, too.  God only knows what else they will find wrong. I have been telling her for a month to get to the doctors office, so I am glad the kids took charge.  I will let you know more as I hear from her.  I need to get Jodi's phone number, the one I have is an old one from before her move several years ago.  Let's keep Jo-Ann in our thoughts and prayers and hope the doctors can pull her out of this mess.  Love MK
Posts.Title: Finally, Jo-Ann's kids took her to the hospital...

Posts.Content:
Gee but aren't we a bunch of stick in the muds? Valentine's day and you were the only one sweet enough to recognize it. I did get a lovely card from my husband with a very special message. I also got a dozen red roses on the 13th because that was the anniversary of the day we met, Feb. 13, 1957. A few years ago....
On the 14th we finally had to let Missy go to doggie heaven. She was getting worse and there was no point of keeping her alive to suffer. She was probably the best dog I ever had and I have had many. I just love animals, especially dogs. Poor Pity has never been without her momma and we have been concerned about
 her. She has health issues, too, and I am sure she is missing Missy. So I started looking at the classified ads and on the internet. I'm sure it was meant to be because within an hour or so I found a male Yorkie who is a bit big for Yorkie standards, he weighs ten pounds and that put him in a much lower price range than the usual Yorkie. The lady sent me a picture and he is so adorable I called her right back and said, "He is mine!" So we are going to meet her sometime this weekend or Monday at the latest. She is in OK north of Dallas so she will meet us part way. His name is Jimmy. Wish I could share a picture.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: HAPPY VALENTINES DAY

Posts.Content:
OK I talked with Jo-Ann this afternoon. I forgot one thing, she is also anemic. They have her on IVs and a clear liquid diet because her blood sugar is still so out of whack. Since she has never seen any of these doctors before, they have no preconceived ideas about
 her illnesses and they will rout out the problems. She laughed when I told her this and said they don't know how contrary she is, either. She told me even her lymphedema arm which is usually quite large is skin hanging on bones. She is one sick lady. They are going to do a complete GI series but when she does not know. I told her I had posted about
 her so you would all know to remember her in prayers. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Finally, Jo-Ann's kids took her to the hospital...

Posts.Content: I read your post yesterday and played your song as I was preparing dinner. Thank you for sharing your music with us. You have a nice soothing voice which I am sure helps your wife immensely. I hope you write and sing many great songs!!!! Mary K. Stroup
Posts.Title: A song I wrote for my wife....

Posts.Content:
Yes, I think it is, also, but I am amazed by the number of women who WANT to go home asap. Rest is one of the best healing factors there is and why anyone is anxious to rush home to all the work and kids when they need to heal is beyond me. I believe most surgeons will keep you in the hospital a couple of days. I think I was there for four eleven years ago. The real chuckle is that my first biopsy done in 1967 kept me in the hospital for 5 days and now it is out patient surgery. The anesthesia is as bad as the surgery. 
MK
Posts.Title: Question about drive-thru Mastectomies

Posts.Content: If she won't listen to anybody, there it makes no sense that you beat yourself trying to get the message across. Are all the hospitals there no smoking facilities like they are here? Maybe a few days of good IV antibiotics, rest and no smoking will help, but she will likely end up with problems again. Sometimes you just have to back off and let people find out for themselves. Your worry over her is not doing you any good, especially this far from her. Take care of yourself. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Sister in England in hospital with cellulitis

Posts.Content: I am so glad to know Cathi qualified, that means good news especially concerning no brain tumors!!!!!! I'm ready to come along to wish her well and give support. Let's show them what good this new trial can do, Cathi!!!! I hope it is a great one for you and helps tremendously!!! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Cathi sends love..

Posts.Content:
We don't have anyone in your area on this board to help with a reference. Have you tried calling the American Cancer Society or looking on websites for names? I'm not really sure where an intern fits into the MD degree but I am pretty sure they have not yet gotten their license. They should be working under the supervision of a full teaching doctor. How can they refuse to do what a doctor suggested, or was it the nurse practioner suggested? IBC is not a cancer to mess with and if there is any chance that you could be diagnosed with it, the earlier the better, so I would not take this lightly. Other cancers in the family history are meaningful in breast cancer. Some more than others. I am no expert on this, but I attended a genetic seminar and that is where I learned there is interest in family members history of other cancers. 
Anyhow I am suggesting you find a specialist somehow. If you can find nothing else, look in the phone book for an oncology center and call there and ask for help. Hopefully you will get someone who has some knowledge or who will direct you to someone who can help you. Also, MD Anderson in Houston is one of the best cancer centers. How far are you from there?
Good luck, let us know what happens. We care. 
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content:
I am sorry to hear about
 your husband.  Sometimes it takes a lot of waiting and worrying to get disability.  I was denied at least three times and the quack doctor SS sent me to thought because I could stoop and bend I was fine walking.  He had no clue what I was dealing with, but thankfully the judge understood and I was granted disability.  Because it took so long I did get a nice check for back payment.  Who in the world would expect a 60 year old person who had already had one stroke to be able to work?

Posts.Title: Glenda it is good to see your post.

Posts.Content:
Maybe we should make a new post with the title "JO-ANN GOT A NEW COMPUTER!!!" 
Yes she is coming to visit on Thursday. I am not sure what we will do, but one thing is to visit the consignment stores in town. This town is full of them, I think it is the only industry here. LOL We have a monthly flea market, too, which I have not visited yet. But it is this weekend, not next.
Jo-Ann celebrated the big 60 on the 3rd and this good friend didn't even send her a card or mention it here. I am hanging my head in shame.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Labor Day Lull

Posts.Content:
Thanks for the update, Lauri. It is wonderful that your eyes are doing so well. Did you delegate your job as travel guide to your sister or was she chomping at the bit to take over? LOL. I don't know why but I think of you and your mother as somewhat the same as my mother and I. I took her on several of my business trips. She lives in a lovely home for the aged now. She is still well enough to get around, but her mind is getting worse all the time. Lately she has been telling me that my dad lived to the age of 91, which would have meant he died three years ago, when 30 is more like it. She has him confused with her father who died at 91. It is so sad to see this happening. I call her every night and lately she is telling me she can't hear me or doesn't understand me. I need to have my brother check out her telephone. 
Don't be surprised if Peter finds someone and moves on. With the internet people are meeting and falling in love much later in life, when they probably would never have ventured out to meet otherwise. My neice and my son's best friend from grade school both met spouses over the internet and married in their forties. They seem exceptionally happy in their marriages, too. Marty and his wife even had a baby! He is a new father while my son is a grandfather. LOL. 
I look in at IV once in awhile and see if any of our old friends post. There are many we have lost track of.
Take care and enjoy the grandbabies.
Hugs MK

Posts.Title: Luci & Lauri.....

Posts.Content: Jo-Ann my grand daughter got the calendar at Kohls.  She saw it going through check out.

Posts.Content:
Don't know about
 the deal she got, but I am gettting her money's worth!!!!
Today's quote: "I want to remind you all that in order to fight and win the war, it requires an expenditure of money that is commiserate with keeping a promise to our troops to make sure that they're well-paid, well trained, well-equipped."

MK
Posts.Title: Jo-Ann for you....A quote from my calendar for today.

Posts.Content:
Actually I have not talked about
 Carolyn too much. She won't talk about
 it much. Not too many people understand what she faces. I tried to Google Elizabeth Edwards to see what I could find out, but most articles seem to be about
 when she was first diagnosed and how they got it all then. 
Thanks for responding Glenda. I hope things get settled for you and your husband soon. It is difficult dealing with the government. I just got back some Medicare payment information for recent tests and visits for us. Medicare did not pay one cent on blood work which is necessary to keep up with the progress of both of our problems. The supplementary insurance will probably pay now. So crazy all this paperwork for nothing and the costs associated with it. 
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Glenda it is good to see your post.

Posts.Content: Will be thinking of you tomorrow and hoping all goes well. When you are able, please let us know how you are doing. You will need help with anything that goes over your head so it would be best to take button clothes to the hospital. You will need help washing your hair and doing a few other simple tasks that require a lot of arm movement. Take it easy and rest. Rest and eating well help the healing process. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: yay!!!!!!FINALLY Scheduled

Posts.Content: Wow has it been two weeks already? I am glad to hear you sound so positive. Honestly a mastectomy isn't as painful as it sounds. The underarm bit is the worst part. It will bother you for some time, but not so you can't handle it. Just do as you are supposed to, do the exercises and don't over do it. Take care, get lots of rest and eat well to heal. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: 2 weeks post op

Posts.Content: I knew as soon as I saw your title what you would be telling us. How terribly sad Vicky has lost her battle. She seemed so full of life and hope. I am glad you got to meet her and spend some time with her. I know it is harder for you to accept her loss after meeting her, but I am sure she set some good thoughts and memories in your heart. God rest her soul. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: sad news

Posts.Content: Thanks Cathi for the nice message. I know it was very hard for you to sit so long and type at the computer. I'm guessing you are more comfortable lying back in a lounge chair or lying down? I can't imagine going through chemo so many times. You are really something!!! I am glad you got a new laptop. Hope you can stop in more often and say Hi, we always love hearing from you. Hugs and prayers, MK
Posts.Title: Hi Friends...just checking in.

Posts.Content: I guess it is time to call and ask her how she is doing. I haven't heard a word. I talked to her when my daughter was dx with recurrence in February. Maybe she has posted a time or two since then. I really hesitate to call because I don't want her to have to be disturbed if she is resting or scramble for the phone if she is not nearby. Please if anyone knows anything, share. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: anyone heard from Cathi W

Posts.Content:
Hi Baq, I wanted to say welcome to Healingwell. It seems to me you are learning about
 this disease and already know more than I do even though I am almost eleven years from diagnosis. I have a daughter about
 your age who learned in February she has a recurrence. She keeps up on all the new treatments and what is happening to her. She is doing well with her treatment right now and even feels ok except she is working too hard and is tired all the time. I waited seven months for reconstruction and my daughter had hers done with the mastectomy. You can find someone here with almost any diagnosis/treatment you might want to know about
. I hope someone will be able to answer more of your questions than I. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: need advice Please

Posts.Content: When I read your post I had to go looking for the post by a nice young man sharing a song he wrote for his wife. It was not this artist or song, but it is good. His name is Tim Julliette and his post is on page 2 if you would like to listen. Now I will listen to Craig Morgan. Thanks MK
Posts.Title: Craig Morgan's song: TOUGH

Posts.Content:
I was stunned when I saw this post although I knew it would be coming one of these days. Like Cathi, I have not heard from Chris for a couple of years. A small acorn grew into a tree of misunderstandings and hurt. It was too bad that it happened and I still blame the village for not helping us when we needed help, but they were commercially interested and did not 
open their eyes to the hurts our ladies were enduring. Ah well, that is passed. I, too, have good memories of Chris and many of the others who are no longer with us. I wish we never had to meet under these circumstances of breast cancer. I wish they never had the pain, physical or mental knowing their time was limited on this earth. Many, many tears have fallen and many prayers have been said and will continue to be said for those who have lost their mothers, friends, life partners, daughters. I am so very sad for all who loved Chris and all the others. Mary K.
Posts.Title: Sad news...

Posts.Content:
I should have read this first before replying to the other post. Somehow I find the idea that hrt could cause a shadow or density pretty distrubing and if being off it for awhile make it go away is even more disturbing. If it can do so much so quickly, is it really good for women to be taking it so easily and frequently? I refused to take estrogen for about
 12 years after my hysterectomy because it caused my blood pressure to rise. Then a doctor talked me into trying the patch. Well, that was a pain in the you know what. I couldn't put it on immediately after bathing because the moisture made it come off, so I would wait and of course I forgot. Then he insisted I try half a pill, then a whold pill............ then the next thing you know I was having a mastectomy and off the pills I went. Did they cause the cancer? Who knows? I took them maybe 5 years and my cancer was very early. So I don't have an answer. I only wonder. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Some good news

Posts.Content: I told you all I had gotten Satellite internet connection.  After spending nearly $500 I am beginning to think I made a very big mistake.  The first few days it worked pretty well, except I don't really like their email format and system.  But three nights ago I got a message from Norton that I had an error and to fix, click on the button.  Well, I clicked and Norton began uninstalling itself and then told me to reinstall when that was done.  I was up until midnight doing all that.  The next day went pretty well until evening when all of a sudden the new WildBlue went crazy.  I called Tech support and told them what was happening and the supervisor told me that she thought it was very strange that Norton would uninstall itself. She suggested I run a FULL scan and look for viruses.  So I ran a full scan and watched as the files flipped by for awhile.  I noticed several strange sounding files with HiKey in them.  There are Hkey files, but when I got back to WildBlue Tech and went to Norton Tech they both said I had a virus or a hacker's spyware. I was told to call a special viral removal number at Norton, another $100 and they would remove it for me.  Well, we were moving right along in spite of the language problems when a huge thunderstorm came up and I lost internet connection.  Guess that happens when you have satellite. So we hung up and an hour later the connection was back so we started again to do the fix and here comes another wave of storm.  So tomorrow morning at 9 am my new friend, "Peter" from India will call me to finish fixing my computer.  Wild Blue email is still not functional, but I am able to be on line and yes it is faster............... I am sooo tired but I did call and leave a message for Jo-Ann.  She never answers her phone anymore.
Posts.Title: One of those rough computer days..................

Posts.Content: Our house is on a lake slough right in the center of the lake. North on 730 to Moran, in that area. It was really country when we bought the house, but there has been quite a bit of building in the area. My husband never stopped working long enough to enjoy the lake. He bought a sailboat to rebuild.................... I have a disability problem and can't walk or stand long so living on the lake or on a farm makes little difference. I enjoy the birds and the trees here. There was a drought for so many years the lake wasn't even nice to look at. Now it is full, thanks to all the rain.
Posts.Title: Some good news

Posts.Content: I am back after a trip home for a big family reunion and a wonderful few days with my brother and family.  My daughter from Cincinnati picked my grand daughter, great grand daughter and I up at the Columbus airport and drove us on to WV for four days.  Hailey, 14 mos, was the hit of the weekend.  She is the best baby I have ever been around and that means many at my age.  She smiles, chatters, goes to anyone, never cries even on airplanes.  She especially was a hit at the Home for Aged where my mother lives.  Yes, we spent time with Mother!! Her short term memory is really bad and her nasty side is making it difficult for the staff at the home.  But she was fine with us.  So we had a nice visit with her, too.  I am going to rest up a few days and today is a great cave day, light rain, overcast skies and I have no reason to go anywhere.
Posts.Title: Labor Day Lull

Posts.Content: I don't remember anyone having discussed thermal imaging. Mammograms really bother some women and others say nothing to it, so maybe you will be in that category even tho you feel tender. Who knows? Since thermal imagining is not "the thing" most doctors use I would think you would have a rough time having insurance pay for it. I'm sure it is very costly! Bite the bullet and get that mammogram done, it is time!!!!!! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Thermal Imaging Scan

Posts.Content:
Hey, if you are ever going to be in Azle, let me know. I will come and meet you. We are still trying to sell our house there, the market is not the greatest. I have family living there, too. It is a small world. I really appreciated the care I got at the hospital there, it was so kind and tender. I actually had tears in my eyes as I left and thanked the nurses and staff. A mastectomy can be difficult mentally, but they were so sweet I never thought of being upset. The food was excellent. Later I went to All Saints several times and it just was not the same, altho the care was good, the food was horrid and I do mean horrid. I am not one who fusses too much about
 food being bad, but it really was. LOL. Don't forget to let me know if you visit Azle. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: lack of results?

Posts.Content:
Oh Patty it is so good to hear from you. I have thought of you often wondering how things were going with you and your husband. I had no idea your son had to go back to Iraq for the third time. Thank God he is home and safe. Your family sounds like it is doing well. I remember your daughter came with you to the group meeting in Cincinnati. So many years have passed since then. 
Yes, we all tried to contact Chris, but she just would not let us in. I haven't been in Cincinnati for a couple of years. My mother is in Wheeling, WV in a home near my brother, so when I go north I usually fly into Columbus and my daughter, Chris from KY, picks me up and we drive to WV and spend time. My son has moved to near Gatlinburg, TN so we go there occasionally. Everyone is scattered anymore. I really would like to get back to northern OH but I never seem to have enough time to fit it all in. 
Please don't stay away so long again. I am thrilled you are doing so well. As far as cancer goes, I am, too. The hernia thing gets more painful all the time, so I do less and less. My daughter has a recurrence of breast cancer after eight years, but so far treatment is doing well and she still works way too hard. They are making hay for their animals and she is right in there lifting and doing it all. Grrr. I wish I could convince her to rest more. Yesterday when I called she was out fixing the hay rake. A couple of days before she was installing a gas water heater. She is her father's daughter, very mechanical, and her husband is not so she usually does the plumbing and electrical repairs. LOL. 
Take care,
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Hello

Judy 
I am so sorry I didn't read and respond more quickly, but if you read my post about
 my daughter you will understand. It is so much worse seeing this darnable disease hit our daughters than ourselves. My daughter was diagnosed eight years ago, two years after I was at age 39 and has just learned she has a recurrence. So we are in this boat together. A boat that neither of us wanted to sail. 
Love and hugs of understanding,

Posts.Title: JUJU HERE

Posts.Content:
Whoa Gretchen you have been through the mill. I doubt that normal even for breast cancer will apply to you. It sounds like your doctors are doing all the right things. Biopsy results take different amounts of time depending on the type of biopsy and who is available to do the reading of the test at the time. Some smaller hospitals have to send everything away, while bigger hospitals have doctors on staff to do the reading. When I had my mastectomy they dtermined the cancer through a frozen section while I was in the OR and since I had signed papers to go ahead, they did. Needle tests can be read immediately, too, if the staff is there. Otherwise it can take a week or even more. Sometimes the pathology can be so different from the normal that it is even sent sent to specialized hospitals for results and that can take several weeks. It doesn't happen often, but it happens. The biopsy can be done in day surgery, but if they decide to do the lymph node it could be more. I hate to sound so uncertain but as with all things there can be exceptions to the norm. Just take care and try not to worry until you know what you need to worry about
. Hugs and prayers, Mary K.
Posts.Title: newbie here

Posts.Content:
Oh Louise, don't be too frightened until you know the details and it is very likely you may not have to be. You didn't mention a biopsy, so I am assuming the picture was pretty positive of cancer. Once you have a pathology report, you will know lots more about
 treatment needed and the type of cancer it is. Some is more aggressive than others. Caught early, bc can be treated with radiology or some of us have even not had that, altho today I think they recommend more treatment. I had a mastectomy and nothing else almost 12 years ago. My aunt had a lumpectomy and radiology about
 20 years ago and nothing else and is doing very well at the age of 80. 
You do what you have to do and keep on trucking. Living with UC has not been a party, I am sure you have kept on trucking there, too. We are here to support and help all we can. Let us know what your path report shows and some can really help you understand it. Be sure to get copies of all reports and keep them in a safe place so you will have them for the future. Good idea taking hubby along, too!
Hugs MK
