Posts.Title: OK, I am trying not to freak out here..........

Posts.Content:
Wow you are coming home after the tram???? What are these doctors thinking? My daughter was bent over by a nurse after her tram and it broke 
open a blood vessel, so they had to whisk her back to surgery. She was going into shock when her other doctor came in and saw her. Please, please, please be careful!!!! The pilot for the pc must be alert
ed so we will get there in time and I will be on it. Hugs for a great recovery, MK
Posts.Title: Need the PC for Tomarrow morning!!

Posts.Content: Sorry the news is not good. Colon cancer is a nasty thing. Prayers from Texas. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Prayers for my ex-brother-in-law

Posts.Content:
It is so difficult to hear such news about
 your sister or anyone you are close to. My daughters are not real close, they are so different, but it really upset one when the other was recently told she has a recurrence. My daughter and I had mastectomies but an aunt of mine was treated as your sister is going to be treated and it has been over 15 years. She has had no recurrence and just turned 80, happy and healthy and strong! Just keep in touch with one another, so she can lean on you when she needs to, but don't fuss or push for details. Let her tell you what she wants but if you feel you need more info gently lead her into the conversation. Does that make sense? My daughter with the recurrence does not like anyone fussing over her and says very little, but bit by bit we get details and share. Take care, be strong and tell her we are here for her if she has a computer and wants to post. Over the years we have had friends from across the pond. Hugs to you both, MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: no recurrence and just turned 80  happy and healthy and strong

Posts.Title: Sister just diagnosed in England

Posts.Content: I hope you hear some good news soon, that he has something very treatable and is on his way to recovery quickly. I will keep him in my thoughts and prayers. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Prayers needed please............

Posts.Content:
Bev, thanks for your insight. I think you might be hitting the nail right on the head. And that goes for how she feels about
 "telling" us all about
 it, too. I talked to her last night and she did get copies of her reports this time. She said the bone scan report shows "activity" but insists that is does not differentiate between osteo arthritis, osteoporosis or bone cancer. Does anyone know if that is usually what the report says? The onc couldn't feel the lymph nodes, but she says she can still feel them, but they have grown smaller. Her friend at work bought her a Chi machine and some kind of hot therapy deal. If you google you can find it easily. At first I thought it might be snake oil stuff, but I looked at it and don't see any problem with using it. 
Ellen, don't worry about
 being mean, I really doubt you are. It is my generation and the one before who were mean and made kids help a lot more. I talked to Miss Natalie and told her I was coming to check her room to be sure and keep it clean for me and then I would reward her in some way. I'm hoping she will keep it clean and get in the habit until she matures enough to care. LOL. Right now she is just a little girl. When I was her age I was so much more mature. I could cook and clean just like an adult, so maybe it is good to give children a little more time for childhood. 
Thanks again for all your help and insight, MK
Posts.Title: Hi MK...how is your daughter?

Posts.Content: Oh Bernadette, I really feel for you. I am one who fought infections for a whole year. I wore an IV antibiotic hook up from August to March. It is a long story but my infection was caused by sutures that were contaminated from the factory. Are you seeing an infectious disease doctor? My PS had one taking care of me right away. I know how bad you feel and I know coming here for a pity party does help some, so feel free to post anytime. A suggestion for you, get copies of your reports and know the infection bacteria and what medicines you are on and keep records. You never know in the future what you might need to know. Hugs, prayers, and all it takes to make you feel better again. MK
Posts.Title: My latest update!!!!! PITY PARTY

Posts.Content:
The others have really covered your questions but I wanted to share a little, too. I think the time it takes can have to do with your 
location and how far the sample has to go to be biopsied. , also. Usually a frozen section is done right away as Lori said but if no one was there trained to read it.......? I guess it would be a moot point. about
 the scar. I had two benign lumps removed before I was diagnosed with cancer. Both times the scar and area filled in and you couldn't see where the lump had been removed. The larger of the two took a little longer filling in, but it did and by the time I had a mastectomy I couldn't remember which breast had which lump originally. So don't be concerned about
 the scar. Let us know about
 the report when it comes back. I hope you hear today. And by the way, you need to get a copy of that report to keep for future references whether it is benign or malignent, and put it in a place where you will know where to find it. Hope you don't have to join us, but you certainly are welcome either way B-9 or other. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: 3 days after lumpectomy....

Posts.Content: For some reason there are people who pretend to have cancer when they do not. We have suspected some who have come to this board, even, but everyone here now is genuine. That said, I can argue the other side. She could have had treatment and stopped, carried or had all her medical records sent to MD Anderson where they gave her the cocktail quickly without scheduling tests yet. I am sure tests should be forthcoming. As for loss of hair, not everyone loses hair, believe it or not. It depends on the type of Chemo they have. Some hair thins a good bit. Some does not. I met one of the board members here after her chemo and she had a beautiful head of long hair. I could hardly believe it. Being ill after the cocktail???? There are good drugs to counteract the nausea which is usually given before the treatment and then again after, so it is possible to not be sick. And sometimes the next day is worse than right after. Many people on chemo gain weight. Usually the very sick pallor does not show up in the beginning of treatment, either. Now I am sure some others will have some input, maybe even disagree with me, because we do not all think alike and certainly others have had more experience with chemo than I have. I didn't have it but my daughter did. She looked fine all through it but she did lose her hair. When it came back it was beautiful altho very short for a good while. So my advice is to believe in your friend, that is what friends are for. If it turns out she was not really truthful, she may have another problem you can help her with. Who would ever want to pretend cancer????? Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Really good friend with breast cancer, but something is not right....advice, thoughts?

Posts.Content:
When I saw your post yesterday I didn't answer you because I hadn't a clue what you were asking about
. I suspect others may have felt the same way. Sclerosis is hardening of tissue, I think. It may be another way of explaining calcifications? That is purely a wild guess. At any rate, it seems to me that you need to be very punctual about
 having your yearly mammogram and exam. Don't let it slip for 6 months or a year. Now I will google and see what I can learn about
 sclerosing lobular hyperplasia. Gee try to say that over and over a few times. 
I checked and came back, it is rare BUT BENIGN, so no wonder I had no idea of what it was. I think the patholgist really knows his stuff there. So take care and follow your doctor's advice. Be happy you have a benign condition now! 
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Is "adenosis and stromal sclerosis" the same as (m)...

Posts.Content: When I looked at the topics this morning, I said to myself, Bev is in a really good mood today! Now I know why. Itis we can live with! Old Arthur is creeping into my hands especially in the morning. He's a member of the family so I have been expecting it. Happy vernal equinox to you, too. It is wonderful to sit on my patio and see green in all the trees now, but the birds have slowed way down. Where did they all go? I hope only to mating season, nesting? Looks like rain, I may take a cave day. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: What I love about cancer...

Posts.Content: Gosh I can't imagine why anyone would think you were over reacting. We have all been there and I know every one of us was frightened. And after the experiences of knowing you do have cancer, every little ache and pain makes you wonder if it is back. I don't suppose they over react to that, either????? Baloney. Sorry you didn't get results yesterday but I am sure you will at your appointment on Tuesday. Just hang in there and enjoy your weekend. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: 3 days after lumpectomy....

Posts.Content: hi my name is brenda and i was dignose in feb. with b-cancer I have gone throw two chem and have had a stint put on. i am coping o.k. but i was wondreringn how do they do a mastectomy done i will have to have one done they say they take it all off but how do they close it with what skin from where?
Posts.Title: Copied to new thread: Brenda005's post with question.

Posts.Content:
Now I will attempt to answer your question. I am guessing since you are having chemo first your tumor could be large and the doctor wants to shrink it first before surgery. At least that was why they did chemo first several years ago. I have heard that they are doing chemo first more often nowno matter the size. 
With any surgery, they do not take the whole area off such as a breast. They 
open it up and take the inside tissue. In fact, there is a nipple sparing surgery if the lump is located so that it can be done. Otherwise they will make a new nipple with reconstruction. Depending on the size of your breast and your intent as to reconstruction, they could do the reconstruction at the same time as your mastectomy. My daughter had that done with a tram flap. Others have had inserts that are slowly filled with saline to reform the breast. And if you are older and your other breast is sagging, you can have it perked up, too, so they match or if you are large breasted it can be reduced and the new breast made to match the reduction. 
Read and ask questions about
 reconstruction if you are considering it and find out what is involved with each type.
Hugs Mary K (MK for short)
Posts.Title: Copied to new thread: Brenda005's post with question.

Posts.Content:
I take Lexapro and have had no problem at all. was her dosage high? I take 10 mg per day in the morning. What kind of reaction did she have? I have taken it for about
 three or four years. I am interested in hearing more? Also I wonder if it could have been a reaction with something else she took possibly like an OTC medicine? Thanks for any more information. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Reaction to lexepro

Posts.Content: Good luck Kathy! I am in awe of you that you are wanting to take on this education! I know you will do well with the interest and drive you have. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Application submitted

Posts.Content:
There is a study under way for sisters of women with breast cancer.  I just sent it on to my daughter that has not been diagnosed with breast cancer to see if she would participate.  I didn't read all the information but it looks like it costs nothing to participate.  There is quite a long questionaire to fill out.  Someone will come to the home I think to take a blood sample, urine sample, a toenail clipping and some dust from the house.  They play to follow up for the next ten years at least.  The way to look into this is to go to 
 .  Or you can call 1-877-4-SISTER  They are trying to enroll 50,000 sisters by the end of the year.  If sisters cooperate I don't think they will have any trouble meeting that number.  It may do some good, who knows?  Think about
 it and talk it over with your sister if you are lucky enough to have one.  Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Did you get a notice of the "sister study"?

Posts.Content:
Hi Letty!
Thanks for posting and participating in the study. I got a really nice card in the mail about
 it and never for a minute thought it was not legitimate. I have two daughters and two years after I was diagnosed with breat cancer the older one was also. Now she has had a recurrence. Her sister had a benign lump removed and she also took infertility drug for several years, so she is being watched closely. She was invited by her physician to join another study but it would have cost her quite a bit, none of the tests were paid for nor did her insurance pay for all of them, and she would have missed work quite a bit. This study seems to not cost a thing and also seems to be more convenient. Please let us know more when you have been tested. 
Thanks and Hugs for helping. Mary K.
Posts.Title: Did you get a notice of the "sister study"?

Posts.Content: Everyone was here yesterday for Easter dinner. As usual she was right in there doing everything from carrying heavy chairs to running the table. She says she feels good. She also mentioned taking Femara. I thought she told me Letrozol but I think the Dr gave her samples of that, and maybe when she had to fill a Rx he changed it? She goes for her third appointment this morning. She will get another IV of the bone strengthening drug and have a blood test and a bone scan. As happens so many times when she is here I was doing my BP and sugar test. She took the cuff and did her BP and as usual it was VERY high. 139/105. I raised my eyebrows and said again why hasn't a doctor given you BP medicine? She just shook it off and said oh well, what's the difference? Grrrr. She is too tough.
Posts.Title: Mary Kay, how are things with Carolyn?

Posts.Content: My daughter is getting an IV treatment for bone strenthening. One of the names for the drug is Boneva. Not sure how to spell that correctly, but it sounds like it is written with a long e sound. Bone Eva You might check into getting that. It can also be taken orally. I am not sure if this is hormone or not. She is also taking hormone drugs, Femara right now. There are also drugs for osteo. I have taken a nose spray called Miacalcin for years. Fosamax is another. Again I am not sure if they are hormone related. It is 4 am here and I am not quite awake. My dogs heard a raccoon on the patio for the second time tonight. They evidently like the bird seed, especially after a good rain when it is all wet cuz they were both sitting there shoveling it in and the light did not worry them a bit. Even this early in the morning I enjoy watching them. I know I am really nuts. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: From breast cancer to osteo in a few months....

Posts.Content:
Yes, my surgery was done 1997. My problem was not the mesh nor was that the name of the mesh used. Mine was definitely the sutures as two sutures were the places the infection first showed up. The surgeon cleaned the suture areas up in Sept. 99 and I was on IV antibiotics from August 99 until March 2000. A suture manufacturer put out contaminated sutures because their autoclave was not working, something like 6.1 million suture sets. A recall was done and only something like 2.3 million was returned. It was on 20/20 in early Sept 99 and on the news but with very little publicity, many people died as a result of the infection. The same sutures are used in heart surgery, etc. I was part of a class action suit and got a rather small settlement considering what it did to my life and mobility. Walking gets rougher each year, I now have a scooter and a walker with wheels and a seat, so I could get around San Antonio better now. LOL. I don't go very far from home anymore. I have seats all over the house to use while I work, two in the kitchen, one in the laundry, one in a storage room. It is not fun but it beats the alternative here, too.
And yes, Glenda, I keep telling Carolyn that she needs to address her BP with the dr. I guess when she sees the dr and it is high they just attribute it to nerves of seeing the dr. I keep telling her I was on BP medicine when I was her age and that she needs to be on it, too. But she is one of those people who believes the less medicine you take the better. My husband is like that. He is to take Nexxium every day and takes it every other day. Grrrrr. Then when he has trouble eating I ask if this is the day you took your Nexxium or not............... I see my dr this Thursday for my annual physical. My doc also sees my grand daughter now who has discussed her mother with her, so I will talk to her about
 Carolyn and her BP. She is in good hands with the oncologist but evidently BP is not something he worries about
? Wish I could get Carolyn to see my doctor, too. 
Thanks for your concerns. Hope both your husbands are getting along better. Mine was quite anemic and Celiac Disease was diagnosed. He has been following a gluten free diet and taking iron tablets and a recent blood test was perfectly normal. He is very good about
 not eating wheat products. He doesn't like taking meds but he really follows the diet without cheating. Bev, I bet you wish you could get your DH to do that, too. 
Hugs to all, MK
BTW I told Carolyn that you all seem to ask about
 her about
 the time for each dr visit. She was pleased to know that. She is on a horse board and talks there about
 her cancer.
Posts.Title: Mary Kay, how are things with Carolyn?

Posts.Content: What would I do without Google? If my mind does not work, I google........... The mesh I had was Gore-Tex. It was fine during the initial surgery where the sutures were infected, but after months of trying to save my abdominal wall, everything was infected and all was removed. I have only the outside skin, fat which I have now overproduced, and then omentum or covering of the intestines, from hip to hip, breast to thighs. I am wearing three binders now which are more comfortable than none or one or two, but they still do not lift the nernia. I called an elastic manufacturer to see if I could buy 3" webbing like is used in binders to design my own. The guy told me they could not sell to the public but he had a roll of black if I could use that he would send it to me. He did and it came last week. 50 yds of strong 3" elastic. Now all I need is Jo-Ann's help and expertise. She seems to be having a rough time right now and I think she needs to come for another visit. LOL. More hugs.
Posts.Title: Mary Kay, how are things with Carolyn?

Posts.Content:
Bev, 
I wanted the 3" stuff because I want to make one of six rows putting two together all the way 3 times and the other seams would go from back to the sides. With 3 "tails" I figure I can get more leverage. In fact, Annie and I talked about
 binders at our first Cincy meeting. Back in the old days the binders were flannel and had many tails, 7 or so, each one being tightened and secured with a safety pin. 
If you still need a binder to fit your hubby, I know just the one. I bought one recently, it is 15", five 3" webs and made for very large people. I bought it figuring it would wrap around at least twice and it almost does. The problem is I can't manage to get it tight enough without DH to help, It is a DARE brand and I bought it at ASAP Medical supply on line. Amamzon has some like it but they are only 4 tiers and not quite as long. I also buy Bird and Cronin 15" binders from an orthopedic place online. 15" are hard to find but I need them long enough to go from breast to thigh. Does he have a problem walking because of the downpull, too? Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Mary Kay, how are things with Carolyn?

Posts.Content:
Oh gees, do I dare say "my new house"? It is not a farmhouse, Joyce, it is a city type house on 34 acres. It is so peaceful and the birds are beginning to find the feeders so it is a joy to watch them. 
Sorry you broke your foot, Joyce. I do think the dr should have told Vic you could do nothing at least until Valentine's Day.
Bev, I know a couple of girls who would love your hot pink suede tool belt. Sounds like a good idea for Jo-Ann and my daughter! Picture, please?
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: What was your favorite Holiday Gift this year?

Posts.Content:
Once again I was out of the loop and didn't have any idea what this was all about
. This morning on the Today show they interviewed the author of the book and the actress who plays her in the movie. It sounds like it will be a good one. Sorry I did not catch either name but I liked the attitude and personality of the young woman who wrote the book. She was 27 when diagnosed. Hugs MK

Posts.Content: Well you know Texas weather. Last week we were in the 20s and had a beautiful snow. Today was a spring like 69.8. I know it is nasty up north and I am sorry you have to deal with it. Posts.Title: So how cold did it get?? (Clutter...)

Posts.Content:
It is in the 20s here today. A snow and ice storm seems to be shaping up to the west of us. We are headed in to Fort Worth to a doctor's appointment. With all the concern about
 my daughter, did I mention my DH has celiac disease? Ugly sounding name, but treatable with a gluten free diet. No wheat or grains containing gluten. After the appt we will go to a store that carries stuff to maintain the diet. Rice flour, arrowroot, all kinds of good sounding stuff?????? More about
 that fun stuff later. Stay warm and have a cave day those of you who are snowed in. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Baby it's cold outside!!!!

Posts.Content: and buying them on eBay.  I brought some to Louisville as gifts.  I just have to share this with you.  In half an hour one of the hardest to find is bidding out on eBay and the bid right now is at $430.  Check it out.  Remember I said one of the rarest............
Posts.Title: Several of you know of my addiction to collecting angels

Posts.Content: Did you do the Electric Slide on the skateboard????? Yeah you shoulda had the camera going. LOL Hugs MK
Posts.Title: some things I MAY be too old for

Posts.Content: It does not sound good at all, but as usual these things tend to happen on Friday afternoon so no matter what, you have to wait at least the weekend.
Posts.Title: Carolyn's bone scan, Friday afternoon, the tech is freaking

Posts.Content: Well I am not sure just what time that concert is to begin tonight, but it is a safe bet Jo-Ann and her son are in their seats excited and waiting. She kept telling me she was not going to go because it cost too much and I convinced her that her son wanted to do this for her and she should graciously accept and enjoy. So here's to a great evening for Jo-Ann. I'm ashamed to admit I don't know Bob Seegar............... guess I am just that much older than she is and when she was going to concerts I was changing diapers and taking care of babies with no time or money for concerts. LOL. To your happiness, my friend. MK
Posts.Title: There are some things that you are never too old for.....

Posts.Content: A little background first.  We have been trying for over a month to have our newspaper stopped at our old house.  I made an annual payment so I did not know the delivery person to call and called the main office.  And called the main office over and over talking to everyone from the janitor to the supervisor yet nothing stopped the paper from coming.  Jo-Ann was here when we were calling.  She and I decided the only way to stop it was to lie in wait some morning.  She thought we were going to do it on the way to Chuck's endoscopy so here is the email she sent me.
Posts.Title: I figure we all can use a Jo-Ann story to make us smile, so I am sharing

Posts.Content:
Deb T, I wanted to ask you when your recurrence was, what year after your original diagnosis? You are over 20 years out from original, right? Your story gives me the most hope. 
The doctor said that it was definitely cancer and the blood test has now ruled out Hodgkins which leaves recurrence. Carolyn has the biopsy set up for Monday afternoon and the bone scan is set for the 9th. Chuck has his upper GI early Monday morning so we will be in Fort Worth but she wants to go alone. My independent daughter who does not like fuss, bother or emotion....... They both work and bought a ranch near our new house, the reason we moved up this way, so no she wouldn't qualify for help. They live in the town we moved from and come to the ranch ion weekends. Their insurance is through a small business situation, hence the not so good insurance. 
And yes, Cathi, I feel exactly as your mother did. It should be me and I wish to Hello it was.
Thanks again for all your love and concern.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: OK Time for a very deep breath.......

Posts.Content: Babies are so special. Grandbabies that you can enjoy and love and pass back for the diapers and crying times are really special!! My new great grand daughter is so loved by her mother that as soon as she whimpers her mother takes her! I have not changed a diaper, either because her mother changes her soon as she gets wet. I am amazed at how often she changes her. OK by me, I will hold her and rock her and cuddle all I can. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Congratulations Sara!

Posts.Content:
Yes insurance does pay for it, at least mine does. Then I also have Medicare that could pay more. Remember I am in the Medicare group. It is becoming a big thing, doing a sleep study. I have even seen bits on News Health programs about
 it. My son in law went through it and his doctor told him he would extend his life 5-10 years. He says he feels much better sleeping with the machine. Well, we'll see about
 that. about
 holding your breath that long, there is no way you could do it awake and alert
 unless you had trained for holding your breath. I understand divers train like that. And I bet there is a place somewhere around there. I am going into Fort Worth but the same DR has another clinic in Weatherford which is a much smaller town. Time to go soon. I'll keep you posted. LOL. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: I'm going to a sleep over tonight..............

Posts.Content:
Joyce, on one of the calls we told them to just deliver the paper to my grand daughter's address and forget cancelling it. Well, they couldn't do that because it was already cancelled and the refund check had been issued. Yes, we got the check for $36. But the paper was there again yesterday. Here is what they finally discovered at the paper office. When I first called in the guy cancelled the paper at the old address, which made the account number drop off the system. Then all the subsequent calls to stop the delivery of the paper were sent to the carriers using the old account number, which no one was showing on their route anymore. Sooooo since no one had that number it was not on their route................ now I think they are trying another method of reaching the right carrier. After all this is a big city with a huge circulation of millions. If not I guess we will have to take action Jo-Ann's way. I am surprised she didn't have us use Mr. Smith and Mrs. Wesson. LOL Next I should tell you about
 Chuck's trip to the real estate tax office. Better yet, Jo-Ann knows that situation, too, maybe she can conjure up a story. How about
 it Jo-Ann using facts, just the facts, ma'm, it is funny in itself. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: I figure we all can use a Jo-Ann story to make us smile, so I am sharing

Posts.Content:
Sara, I can't imagine hiding your beautiful face behind the mask. I know your husband travels a lot, but he's too good looking for you to be hiding behind the mask all night when he is home. LOL.
Joyce, you mean to tell me you wouldn't let Vic go on a sleep over. You know I have spent two nights there now and have yet to see another soul except my own technician. I know there are others there because the techs have more than one patient a night and there are two or three techs. I wished I had taken my camera and asked her to take a picture for Chuck. The rooms and beds are very comfortable and quiet.
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: I'm going to a sleep over tonight..............

Posts.Content:
I thinj it is wonderful that you keep in touch with Benito so faithfully. He sounds like a great guy and I am sure he is happy to see you and talk. Thanks for telling us about
 Mike, too. Wouldn't JoAnnie be proud of him? She already was when he was still in HS. Thanks for sharing and keeping us updated. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Had lunch with JoAnnie's "Benito" today...

Posts.Content:
I came to this board about
 eight years ago because two years after I had been diagnosed with breast cancer my oldest daughter (age 39 then) was diagnosed and I was beside myself.  Well, she found some lumps near her clavicle last week and today saw her oncologist who had given her a five years bill of health.  He is almost certain it is breast cancer.  They did blood tests and the lymph nodes are not enlarged because of infection.  She had a CT scan last Friday showing the nodes enlarged, which was ordered by her regular doctor.  She will have a full bone scan on the 9th and a biospy as soon as it is scheduled.  Once again I wish I were the one facing this and not her, but things don't always end up as we wish them to be.  Please keep her in your thoughts and prayers.  Thank God Jo-Ann is here for a visit, it helps so much.  Hugs MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: cancer my oldest daughter  age 39 then  was diagnosed and I

Posts.Title: OK Time for a very deep breath.......

Posts.Content:
Thanks for your understanding. It has been eight years since Carolyn's diagnosis. She had no positive nodes but was given chemo, 4 rounds because of her age. She turned 40 just as she finished. She had a mastectomy so she did not have radiation. Her lump was high on her breast and was rather long. It was classed as a Stage 2 because of the size. She took Tamoxifen for awhile but it caused her to be really depressed which is certainly not her. She was not good about
 going for yearly check ups but she did go for her five year check ups and mammagram and all looked fine then. 
I am not worrying until we hear what the out come is as to where it is located. So far the CT scan showed her internal organs to be ok. She has been experiencing terrible back pain for several months so that is what we are concerned about
. Another concern is that they have lousey insurance. I think it pays only 80% after a big deductible, so the cost of chemo is frightening. The oncologist seems to feel sure it is breast cancer returning or the second guess is Hodgkins. Either way he is saying it is most likely cancer. 
Hugs MK

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> She turned 40 just as she finished <Z>

Posts.Title: OK Time for a very deep breath.......

Posts.Content:
What a wonderful trip. We had a Japanese exchange student when my kids were in high school and her mother and two sisters also came to visit while she was with us. They were wonderful friendly women. I always wanted a chance to go to Japan and visit them but it never happened, so I really envy your trip. Thanks for sharing. I was surprised to hear about
 the Relay for Life, too, altho I am not sure why. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Back from Japan

Posts.Content: No, I really didn't know what I was doing, I simply liked them and wanted them. The more of them I saw, the more I had to have. I have the full collection of the "Retired Angels" And I think I have all the Heavenly Angels like you have, Deb. They are not quite gaining value as rapidly as the old ladies and men. They are fun to watch on eBay, tho. Another Ms. Penny Saver went for $255.03 the other day. Ms Alice Goody the nurse is listed at $250 beginning or buy it now, but I don't think she is as scarce as to bring that yet. Will keep you up dated. LOL. MK
Posts.Title: Several of you know of my addiction to collecting angels

Posts.Content:
Hi Angela, I didn't realize it was you, either and if you read my other post you can imagine right now I am not in the best frame of mind to be posting uplifting messages to newbies. I am sorry to hear about
 your cousin's wife. I will keep her in my thoughts and prayers, too. Cancer just keeps rearing it's ugly head. My daughter's first husband, her two kids father was just diagnosed with thyroid cancer that had also spread to the lymph nodes. His fiance was dx with breast cancer last year at stage III. So my two grandchildren are really dealing with a lot of cancer right now. They are both grown but that doesn't make it any easier on them. I hate this terrible disease!!!! But I love all the friends I have made through it. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Hey Ladies, I know it seems that I only come around when I need you...

Posts.Content:
What a great supportive thread this is. You guys are the greatest!!!! I didn't respond earlier because I was blessed by not having to go through all this after having a mastectomy. When I read about
 your experiences it makes me feel humbled to know you all. 
Cathi I met a woman last week at the community concert that reminded me of you, she looked like you when we first met. She was wearing a BC cap so I spoke to her and told her I was almost ten years out. She said she was six years out and this was the third time she was going through chemo. 
I also met Angela Dula's twin at the sleep clinic. You know they say everyone has a twin somewhere, this woman looks and smiles just like Angela. 
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Feeling overwhelmed with treatments

Posts.Content:
I'm fine. We are iced in for the most part. Luckily, DH was off for 4 day shift turn around and didn't have to drive that long way to work. He did manage to get to the other house yesterday to check on things. I am here covered up with boxes to unpack yet and stuff to figure out and arrange. My DGD who was such a big help went to Milwaukee to be with her father while he is waiting to have surgery for a thyroid cancer. She'll be back next week and will come and help me some more then. His cancer is in early stages and should be ok, but she wanted to be with him. She's a wonderful young lady. 
I have been keeping track of the board several times a day, just not taking time to post because I really have little to add. You all are so much more knowledgeable to help newbies than I am. But I am behind you 100% and keeping everyone in my thoughts and prayers.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Calling MK and Jo-Ann..are you ok?

Posts.Content: So here I am again, dragging tail and needing a good swift kick in the behind. I can tell you had a marvelous birthday and thankfully you did not have to hear me sing. But I do want to wish you a belated Happy Birthday. Hope all is well in your side of PA. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday to our Captain Lemon !!...(Joyce)

Posts.Content: The onc has put my daughter on Letrazol which is another name for Femara for a month to see how it works for her.  Today she was given an IV of Boneva which is a bone strengthening drug. When she goes back in a month she will have another IV of that and the tests to see how she is doing.  I suggested that she get copies of her reports but she didn't, they were too busy because the doctor had been away for a week.  Rolling my eyes.  She is taking muscle relaxants and pain medication from the regular dr.   She went back to work this afternoon and is trying to catch up on the work she missed Friday and today.  That's all I know. She told me her husband told her she better hurry up and get better because there is a lot of fence repair to do on the ranch.  He was joking..................  but knowing her she will probably be doing it.  She is one tough woman, wants to take it all on herself.  Still wish I could trade, but I am hoping this medication will be the kind that works and works well for her.  Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Here's the course of action for the next month at least.

Posts.Content:
I just realized from this post that her time to be checking in with her oncologist should be this week. She will not say much. She insists the pain in her back, which is evidently quite severe because it brings her to tears when she moves wrong, is from a muscle not any bone cancer. She has been to a chiropracter several times and yesterday had a massage by therapist a doctor had recommended to someone else. Evidently she gets a little relief but then her work requires standing and bending in such a way that it causes pain again. She is cheerful usually, unless you catch her when she is really hurting and full of stress. She puts on a happy face and continues to do way more than she needs to or should. She is still hauling big bags of feed for the horses and cows instead of leaving them for her son or husband to do. Grrrr. I try not to be a buttinsky and let her tell me what she wants. I think it is harder to try to suggest to your own daughter what she needs to do than it is a friend or a stranger. Soon as I know anything about
 her next onc appt I will let you know. Thanks for asking. And thanks for the hugs, we both can use them. Hugs to you all, too. MK
Posts.Title: Here's the course of action for the next month at least.

Posts.Content: There is an ignore choice. Use the thumbs down button and you won't have to be bothered anymore. The posts have been strange but have not really crossed the line. Enuf said. MK
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer...

Posts.Content:
Sorry, it has been a crazy time around here again.  DH had his annual physical and blood work done and was found to be anemic.  So the PC has ordered every test possible to check and find out why.  We did something every day this week Xrays, CT, more blood work consulting dr.  So far nothing has been found except age and it's changes.  He is going for an endoscopy and colonoscopy near the end of the month.  Taking iron and trying to eat more is about
 all he can do right now.  Imagine trying to eat more.  Geezh!
Posts.Title: Guess I should check in....

Posts.Content:
"shows cancer consistent with earlier breast cancer."  Next comes her bone scan and then meeting with the oncologist to determine course of treatment.  She is really frightened about
 the bone scan, it is scheduled for Friday but she was trying to get it moved up to Wednesday today.  I need to call and see if she was able to.   I will let you know about
 those test results as soon as I hear.
Posts.Title: Biospy done today on my daughter

Posts.Content: I am late, too. I am hoping you had a wonderful birthday with lots of special happenings. Wish we all lived close enough to do lunches for birthdays like we used to do at work. That is a little hard to meet from Texas to Virginia, isn't it? Enjoy each day of this new year. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday Beck2000... the best thing about January...

Posts.Content: Welcome to an old friend!!! I am glad you found us, thanks to Lori. Oh my but you have been through a lot!!!! What a strong young woman you are to have dealt with so much in so short a time. Bless your heart!!! I hope you will find some good support here, too. Many of your old friends are here, but not everyone weighs in every day, so it may take a week or two to hear from many of them. I will keep you in my prayers as you face this new decision. As Lori told you, Cathi has had problems with bone mets and the chemo was very hard on her other medical problems, ei diabetes. She has taken some time off this summer. We have a couple of women who have taken some time off treatments to regroup and then began again. I hope you will feel at home here. Hugs, Mary K. (MK)
Posts.Title: thanks for the invite, Lori, I'll introduce myself...

Posts.Content: It shouldn't matter where you go to get a biopsy done, but it should be done. Early detection and treatment is always best. When the radiology report says suspicious you need to take it seriously. Six weeks may not mean a whole lot time wise, but in six weeks there could be another reason to wait a little longer. I would feel better if I were in your shoes knowing what I was dealing with and getting it taken care of. In fact once I heard that word suspicious I was ready to deal with it immediately. That was ten years ago and I have had no further evidence of cancer. Since you have already dealt with cancer, I really wouldn't wait. Hope all goes well. Let us know. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Radiology report

Posts.Content: Thank you all so much. I had a low key birthday, but I got two bouquets of flowers. Erica brought my ggdaughter and stayed for supper. No cake but I am having a big dish of Blue Bell Dutch Chocolate Ice Cream. Talked to several family members and got lots of cards. You all sent such nice messages. So how could it be any better? I guess I will get ready for bed and read while DH is watching the ballgame. Love and Hugs to all, MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday, MaryK.............

Posts.Content:
Yes, Ellen I understand the pain and the scary feeling, especially when you have been through it once. I keep getting this strange pain in my reconstruction. Could cancer be lurking beneath? How could we tell if it was? And once in awhile the other breast hurts. Is it imagination or is it real? Who knows? I kept telling myself nothing is wrong, the mammo did not show anything last spring and it is almost time again. Then comes Carolyn's news............... So, you see at least one of us shares your fright. Not that I am really frightened of having a recurrence and losing the battle. It worries me more about
 surviving and not being able to take care of myself. I would gladly give my body up so Carolyn would be safe, but I guess we have to take what we get. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: baby steps

Posts.Content: WEll, it took a little time to get the mask adjusted and the machine pressure set. Then it took a little time to get used to it. She brought me a second mask that was a larger size and it worked better. I slept from midnight to 5 am then went back to sleep for another hour or so. She said I did well, but I will not know the real results until I see the dr. That appt is not set yet. I will keep you posted. I am hearing of more and more people who sleep with the machines. I am wondering what the dogs will think when they see me with the mask on. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: I'm going to a sleep over tonight..............

Posts.Content:
Yes Jean, it does happen. I personally have not had a problem, nor did I have radiology, but one of our dear members a few years back had pretty severe heart problems. I am not sure it was radiology or if it was chemo. She lived in OK at the time and the doctor treating her for heart problems unfortunately erred in her treatment. She moved to Atlanta GA and went to a new doctor. Just as he was getting a handle on her problems her heart gave out. We were all so upset because it was so unnecessary. Her heart beat was very erratic as I recall. I am not telling you this to frighten you, but to point out it can happen and once again we must advocate staying on top of what the doctor is doing and how much he/she knows. Take care and keep us informed as to how the tests go. 
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Heart Damage from Radiation ??

Posts.Content: Di, I am sorry you have to deal with so much illness. Seems like you have had more than your share for quite some time. You have been such a fighter in the years we have been together. You sure have been loyal to all of us in support, too, so you know we are all here for you. Just remember there is not a thing you can do to change what is happening except to give support and love and I know you are doing that. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: prayers needed for loved ones

Posts.Content:
I got an email from Elizabeth Edwards the other day about
 her new book "Saving Grace" that is due out. It is supposed to be about
 the support of family, friends and strangers and how much it helped her. Amazon has it listed for $16.95 for preorder and you can get it through the Amazon connection here and help Healingwell at the same time. 
I can't figure out why you would be getting elephant mail, Joyce. It should be from the donkeys............. lol. Gees I love the way the powers of internet send us emails after things we do. My grand daughter uses my computer to check into things for a new mother and her interests and now I am plagued with emails for baby stuff etc. And I try not to stray into unknown territory that might take me near something that is a no-no subject, all of a sudden emails come from them, too. The other day I was googling something and almost hit the wrong selection, am I glad I caught myself.
Meanwhile I am still in a strange mood and not real excited about
 posting, altho I do keep an eye on the posts. Big hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Do any of you remember...

Posts.Content:
Dear Cathi, this is not the message I wanted to read today! I am so, so sorry you are having to fight so hard. I am glad SSI worked so well for you, it did for Jo-Ann, too. I have been in the doldrums about
 posting here, altho I do read often. I had to answer your post tonight to tell you I am on your side and thinking of you. Please enjoy every moment with your kitty. I know she is precious and how much joy she will give you. We all love you, you know that. MK
Posts.Title: Here we go again...and again....

Posts.Content:
Heavens no I was not in on the bidding. I already got one several years ago, and it was the last one to complete my collection. I paid around $60 for mine. I had only seen that one until this one was put up for bid. I was astonished at the price it brought. The originally sold for $40. There are still a few available in gift shops but Rubel quit making them about
 three years ago and some are more rare than others. I think Greta is the hardest to find. A Bargain Shopper angel sold for $278 last week. The ones I brought to LV were Flora Sweet which Libby got and Alice Goody the Nurse and I don't remember who got her. I watch as they are listed and when the sell well print the results for my kids to know the value in the future. LOL My way of investing????? DH thought I was nuts buying these angels but I think he is beginning to think maybe I wasn't quite as nuts as he thought. LOL. 
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Several of you know of my addiction to collecting angels

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday a week late and a dollar short. I am sorry to be late and hope you had a great one with hubby and Tavish. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday LoriG...TAVISH.......

Posts.Content: Tram flap surgery is serious surgery. It takes time to recover and you have to really take it easy for awhile, but the end result is usually the best. A tummy tuck if you need one is a great asset of the tram. You end up with natural looking breasts and they grow with you as you get older. Trust me I know that. LOL. Just don't expect to come home and do what you did before surgery for a few months. Many of us have had the surgery, so ask away. I did not like the lopsided feel with the prosthesis myself. Possibly one of us is near you and also had the same surgeon. I am in the Fort Worth, TX area, where are you located? Hugs of welcome, Mary K.
Posts.Title: Tram flap surgery

Posts.Content:
It has been a long time since we have heard from her.  For all she has been through and is still going through she sounded wonderful and we talked a good while.  She said to tell you all she sends hugs and kisses.  She also said that it is hard to post because she doesn't want to share her struggles which may seem negative to newbies.  I told her she is one of our success stories staying here on this earth for much longer than the doctors predicted.  She asked about
 many of you that she met in Cincy and knew through the board.  Keep her in your prayers as she continues her battle and goes through a hip replacement in the next month or so.  Hugs,  MK
Posts.Title: I just got off the phone talking with Cyndy in Indiana.

Posts.Content: We are far from being unpacked and there is still more stuff to haul here, but for the most part this is now home. I just wanted to stop by and tell you I am thinking of you all.  My mother is here visiting and seeing new home and new great, great grandbaby.  So I will be scarce.  I need to find a new source of internet.  Dial up is connected so slowly it is a real pain.  Love and hugs to all,  MK
Posts.Title: We are moved but exhausted!!!!

Posts.Content: Someone needs to answer this question who is much more knowledgeable than I am. Or you can google stages of breast cancer to get some help if you are in a hurry. Briefly, stages go from I to IV. Stage IV is usually when there is mets which is spreading. Stage I and II are differentiated by size of tumor as well as a few other factors. I was lucky and caught my cancer early and my staging is barely I. In fact the onc I saw drew a chart and showed me how each factor of mine fit it. I think there were all zeros but one I. It was a long time ago and my memory gets worse every day. Grade II is not terrible. My daughter was graded a II and she was dx in 1999 and has no further evidence of disease or NED as we call it here. Hope this helps a little. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Ok Ive been reading again!!!!!

Posts.Content:
Better late than never to say Welcome. It seems as tho everyone is giving you good advice and all sounds like you have a great doc. My usual advice is not to worry until you know you have something to worry about
. The biopsy will provide information that you need. Keep in touch and let us know. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Calcifications

Posts.Content:
Hey it WAS a full moon!!! I about
 died when I looked out the window that night and saw a full moon. But, Bev, don't give me credit you hunted that one out. I hadn 't even read it. Oh well we should be ok for another three weeks now. LOL Hugs MK
Posts.Title: there seems to be a rash that's going around...

Posts.Content: YES!!!!!!! We love to hear that word B-9. I know how relieved you are! You have enough going on to deal with this stuff, but please stay current with mammograms and exams..... So happy for you, Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Calcifications

OK Ellen don't worry before you know you have something to worry about
, right? You can tell us all about
 the new Dilon scan and be our source of information for newbies having them. Have you moved into your new home yet? Think positive and tell us all about
 it. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: a little worried

Posts.Content:
LOL Lori! I can just picture all that! I could tell from his pictures how much he loves you. He looks pretty cuddly, too. 
The tech told me I did very well with the machine. Today I had a phone call from the service who will come to the house and fit me and set it all up for me. She told me my insurance will totally pay for it all and I have very good insurance. That is always good to hear. Posts.Title: I'm going to a sleep over tonight..............

Posts.Content:
You will certainly have my prayers as you go through the tests and for the insurance to come through for you. This journey seems to be interupted often by the dreaded "waiting". I personally agree with the mastectomy and the bilateral seems like a great move considering your history. I don't remember your age, but the trams I would think about
 long and hard. Many of our sisters choose to have the bilateral without reconstruction and are certainly free with respect to clothing and ability to do more things. You can get prostheses for dressing up. Just another thought to consider. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Extra prayers needed

Posts.Content: Hi Vaultene and welcome. It seems as though you have already been through a lot. I hope we can help you with your current journey. I saw you had two posts and the one had no subject and was missing the text, so I deleted it thinking of space on the board. Now I realize you were trying to put a line on the bottom of your post. You can still do that by going to the post and clicking on the pencil symbol on the right hand side. Then you can edit your own posts. If you make a mistake on a future post and want to erase and start over, the X will delete it for you. Don't delete the one above though, because by deleting the first post you delete the whole thread. Thanks for posting, hope we can help. Did you check out our roll call post? It is long but there are some pictures of us in there, too. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: New to Here

Posts.Content: More prayers from Texas for you and your husband and the rest of the family in this difficult time. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Need Prayers

Posts.Content:
When I read your title, I thought you were talking about
 still unpacking from the move. LOL But when I realized you were finalizing wedding plans, I got a little more enthusiastic. You sure are down to the wire and it sounds like you have everything well under control. Oh my! Your honeymoon sounds like heaven!!! Places I always wanted to see and this old bod will never make now. I am soooo jealous. Who will take care of Tavish????? I am so sorry to hear he is hurting and can't run and play. I picture him as ths little bundle of love, joy and activity and can only imagine he is chomping at the bit to be free to go again. Give him some squeezes for me.
Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: linens and programs and shoes,oh my! (clutter)

Posts.Content: Congratulations and wishes for many more years!!! I also want to say you have been a steady and important member of our group on breast cancer support. Your help and knowledge has helped many, many of our sisters. We know we can count on you and appreciate you!!! Big hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Seven years and counting!!!

Posts.Content:
I think you could go ahead and make your trip. A few days is not going to make that much difference. Schedule the biopsy for when you get back. Once you have it done then you will have time to make any arrangements you might need to make amd you might be more relaxed to make them. DON'T fret and worry about
 the biopsy while you are gone, there could be no reason for worry so why waste time worrying? 
I have no idea about
 the insurance, but I am hoping and guessing that because it is the same company perhaps you will have no trouble getting it changed to your husband's plan. PPOs are usually higher in cost and I would think that would be in your favor rather than the opposite scenario. 
Let us know what happens. We will help all we can. Be sure to get copies of all your path reports and mammo reports to keep in your own files. It will lbe helpful in the future even if this turns out to be benign. You aren't the first 53 year old to wait for a mammogram so don't beat yourself up over it, but be sure to share your story and urge your friends to go for theirs.
Hugs and best wishes, MK (Mary K.)

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> You aren't the first 53 year old to wait for

Posts.Title: Birad 4 - wondering whether to make trip

Posts.Content:
What is the major city? Perhaps here you can find someone who has actually had treatment in the area. Some doctors are very knowledgeable about
 breast cancer and others........well they leave a lot to be desired. How was she diagnosed? She has the right to get a copy of the pathology of her biopsy. That can also help in making a decision about
 a doctor or what method of treatment. I, too, find it hard to believe she was not advised about
 choices. Give us more info and perhaps we can help better. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Friend just diagnosed last Friday 10/06/06

Posts.Content:
Now wait just one cotton pickin' minute. I have all of you beat by ten years and you are thinking you are old???? I went to the eye dr the other day and the chair I sat in was across from a huge mirror. Talk about
 seeing a fat old lady in the mirror. Thank God my eyes were dialated half the time I was there and I couldn't see. Yesterday I fixed a mini version of our Thanksgiving dinner. I was sick and DH had to work on turkey day, so this was his first day off to enjoy the bird. I fixed less than half the different foods I would have normally fixed and I was so tired, Chuck did the dishes!!! Today is not only a cave day for Jo-Ann and I but an ice cave day in our part of the woods. I am going to settle back, read and eat left over turkey and pumpkin pie. LOL. Bet none of you can say you are still eating turkey leftovers--unless you froze some. Thanksgiving prayers for our old bodies that are still able to move around even if we don't look like we used to. When I look in the mirror, I don't see my mother, I see my grandmothers and that is no joke it is the truth. Hugs to all, MK
Posts.Title: Facing some very hard facts.........

Posts.Content:
Have you checked out the Roll Call at the beginning of the board? There are actually some pictures of us when we met so you can put faces with names. We do have some wonderful women here. Some of us have been hanging together for nearly eight years.
I thought of pre existing conditions but since it was the same company, I thought perhaps it wouldn't matter as much. I will be interested in knowing the details of the insurance deal. 
Incidently, when I was called back for a second mammo I had a business trip to Vegas of all places and had to delay getting it done when I got back. That was ten years ago this month.
Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Birad 4 - wondering whether to make trip

Posts.Content:
I got a wonderful sign for my kitchen for Christmas from my daughter. GRANDMA'S HOMEMADE BAKERY Fresh Baked goods Made with Love. It is about
 4' x2' in size. You'd love it. I can stay here all day and bake my little heart out. 
Anyone who wants to visit my little piece of farmland heaven is welcome. Of course Chuck is going to purchase a real tractor again. No, no animals, but maybe some chickens??? I'd like to have fresh eggs. Lots and lots of birds are around, but I have yet to see one duck. Blue jays, Cardinals, Bluebirds, Woodpeckers, Hawks. So far I have not seen a little sparrow. Robins were here last week but they must have moved on. Chuck also saw Cedar Waxwings before we moved in. 
All is going well with Mother, too. She doesn't remember where she is half the time and asks over and over whose house this is, where is it, etc. Poor soul, I actually ache for her. Her health is great, tho.
Hope you all had a wonderful day. 
Love and Hugs, MK
PS happyhannah did you check out the roll call above and see our pictures?
Posts.Title: Help needed here!

Posts.Content:
It's the farm, Joyce, but only 34 acres. It has two ponds, a lovely creek when there is no drought, and lots of nice trees and landscaping around the house. He has a 36 x 36 ft metal bldg to play in and is taking his boat to work on it there. No crops, no animals. He is going to seed for hay. I had agreed to move when we found a house on one floor with my own bedroom that I could keep cool. He has one where he can get as warm as he wants. The kitchen is to die for. It is 29 x 19.5 feet. With 40 linear feet of counter top to work on. I could have a cooking school there. LOL. Seriously, we are planning a 
cookie bake a week from Friday when my two grand daughters and daughter will come to make Christmas 
cookies. My other stipulation was that the house not need to be remodeled, insulated or any major work done. This house was built by a retired couple in 1995. It is dirty but I am hoping I can get help up there to clean. 
Now are you ready for a real shock??? I called my brother to send Mother for Christmas, too. I know I am really nuts, but she really wants to see her great, great grand daughter as well as Carolyn's kids. She has mellowed so much I hope it will be a pleasant visit. More later. I will email you some pictures. Gotta run packing the china. Chuck is on a run to the new house with the van loaded with angels and Rubel animals. Yes, he even helped me pack them. But he is going to work until this house is sold then retire. Hopefully that will happen soon. Hugs MK

I live in TX but I went to Boston for nurse's training a hundred years ago, it seems. It was the best for medical schools then and I am sure it still is. I don't think we have anyone here on the board right now who goes to Dana Farber, but we have had in the past. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Friend just diagnosed last Friday 10/06/06

Posts.Content: I was thinking as I read your title... I haven't had a grandson for almost 15 years. My first grandchild was a boy and he is now a man with a daughter of his own. I do have two darling great grand daughters, but I am a little envious of your new grandson. I hope all goes well tomorrow and he is in your arms cuddling soon. Best wishes to you all. Love MK
Posts.Title: New Grandson a comin'!!!!

Posts.Content: It is amazing what blood tests show. I am glad to hear you will be having one next week. I bet you will get some answers then. I sure hope you are feeling better soon. MK
Posts.Title: Feel Like I'm Doing Chemo Again

Posts.Content:
Once again I have learned something new. Thanks Candy for helping out and researching this information. 
As far as whether it should be removed or left alone, my inclination would be to have it removed. Why leave something there that does not belong? Is there any chance it could have cellular changes? I sure don't know, but if I had a lump I could feel I know I would feel it constantly to see if there was any change. Kind of like having a broken tooth and having your tongue constantly rubbing against it. Biopsies are not difficult surgery at all, she would be relieved to have a pathology report telling her that it is benign and she would not have to feel that lump. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: My Sister has a harmatoma?

Posts.Content: Thank you for letting us know, Lori. I remember her, of course. It is a shame we keep losing wonderful young women. Only 37, so much life to live and enjoy. I have kept a list of sisters lost and she is number 35. Prayers for her family and friends. I feel so sad to have lost another member of our group. Love, MK

Posts.Title: Happy birthday, Luci

Posts.Content: I didn't do chemo and have no help for you there, but I sure would be on the phone calling the doctor. The symptoms you have could be caused by other problems. Any chance of being a diabetic? That was my first thought. The swollen legs and feet could be blood pressure problems. You definitely need to be checked. Let us know what you find out. Hugs and prayers, MK
Posts.Title: Feel Like I'm Doing Chemo Again

Posts.Content:
Thanks for the pictures. Gavin is really beautiful and looks so alert
 already. I know you are a proud Grandma and have every reason to be. Spend as much time as you can hugging and holding him. There is nothing like being a Grandma. Hugs of congratulations, MK
Posts.Title: Pictures!

Posts.Content: I was going to say I bet your hair looks real cute, too. You beat me to it. The hair that I have seen grown out after chemo has always been so pretty, shiny and curly. My daughter just turned 40 when her hair came back and it was beautiful salt and pepper. She hated that it looked so dark because she had always been blond, so she lightened it. Now she has let it go natural, seven years later and it still has a beautiful salt and pepper color to it. Enjoy the carefree days of washing and combing.............. Hugs MK

Posts.Title: I came out of my wig!

Posts.Content:
Definitely go for a second opinion. If you have a breast specialist in your area, try and see them. The only way to know for sure is to do a biopsy. It seems to me there are places that can be biopsied if you feel hard lumps. You need answers not guesses so you can rest easy. Breast cancer does not always mean big problems. Early detection and getting treatment can be all it takes for a longer lifetime. I was diagnosed ten years ago and there are several more around here that far out. One of us is approaching 25 years I believe. Try not to worry until you really have something you know needs worried about
. We are here to help once you get some more answers. Hug, Mary K.
Posts.Title: dx inconclusive

Posts.Content:
There are no stupid questions and this certainly is not one. Yes, mets stand for metastasis which is the spreading of breast cancer through the body. Breast cancer is a particular kind of cancer and if it spreads to other parts of the body, it is still breast cancer not the kind of cancer which would be primary to that would be found in that area. Brain mets is breast cancer that is in the brain as opposed to a primary brain cancer. We have had sisters with about
 all kinds of mets. Bone, Lung, Brain, I think have been the most common. The removal of lymph nodes tells the doctors if your cancer has spread to the lymphatic system and the staging is done from this test and others from the pathology report. Hugs, MK
Posts.Title: I have a stupid question

Posts.Content: No apron, Joyce!! This is a guy who avoids the man next door because he told him he "loved" him!! I have tried and tried to explain he didn't mean he "LOVED" him he just meant "I get a kick out of you and like you". Nope, can't convince him, he stays away when he sees him out. LOL Men. Posts.Title: Question for forum moderators...

Posts.Content:
Oh Cyndy, am I so glad to see you!!!! It has been a long time and if I remember correctly the last time we heard from you, you were having problems of some kind. Many times I have thought about
 trying to call, but I have this problem with procrastination in my old age. I even procrastinate posting here. I need a good swift kick. It is wonderful to hear you are contemplating a hip replacement. Just like celebrating the old Artheritis, no place else would that seem like good news!!! Hope your girls are doing well, too. How about
 the one who wanted to be a doctor? My granddaughter is in her third year of medical school and still loving it and doing well. She is at U of KY Lexington. All's well here in Texas. We are negotiating to buy our dream retirement home, 34 acres for DH to play on and a home on one floor with a kitchen to die for. It is so big and has almost 40 feet of counter top where I can roll pie dough, make bread--heck hold a cooking school if I like. I did not want to move again, but this place changed my mind. It is about
 50 miles from here near Bowie, TX. Our daughter and husband bought a ranch up that way. Love and hugs to you, too. Mary K.
Posts.Title: checking in

Posts.Content: Hi Viv, Glad to see you posted. Be sure and stay in touch and let us help you over any bumps you may meet. I hope all is going well with any treatments, etc. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Viv, it was good to see your post!

Posts.Content:
What Joyce says is very true. You can have more than one "Primary" cancers. You can even have more than one kinds of "breast cancer" in your breasts. That's why it is important to always have a biopsy and a pathology study done. And you can learn something new about
 cancer every day. However, I must say the TV news sometimes gives me a good chuckle when they say what can cure or cause cancer. Hugs MK

I had some after my mastectomy which were drained via needle and not called seromas by that surgeon but they were just the same. Hope all is going well and no infection starts up. Keep us posted. Hugs MK

Posts.Title: Happy Birthday Cathi!

Posts.Content:
I mentioned in my other post about
 being upset and causing hot flashes. I also think that hot flashes are kind of like pain thresholds, some have much worse flashes than others. A friend of mine actually wore a winter coat sweater around the office when it was so hot the rest of us could die, because she would freeze to death after having a major flash. I never would have believed any one body could swing from hot to cold like she did. I hated having flashes but they were nothing compared to what she went through. I hope you are able to find something to ease yours. My dr prescribed Lexapro for me because I was having anger/rage spells. I know when I was having hot flashes that would have triggered them big time. The Lexapro does help me now. Mary K.

Posts.Content:
Joyce is our resident expert on IBC! I even learned something new reading her post this time. Altho over the years she has told lots about

Posts.Title: It's officially IBC

Posts.Content: I hope by now you have decided to push for a biopsy. Not all masses are cancer, certainly, but not all cancer masses look the same nor do benign ones. The best way to know is to have a biopsy. There is a needle biopsy which is easier than surgical biopsy which is not a difficult surgery at all. Personally I would want a surgical biopsy because the needle could possibly hit off the mass, especially if it is a movable mass. However, if cancer is suspected and a needle biopsy confirms it, so much the better. In your case they seem to be saying they believe it is benigh. Keep us posted as to what is happening, please. We care. Hugs MK

Posts.Title: My daughter has cancer.......

Posts.Content:
One thing I learned about
 hot flashes..... if something upset me even the least little bit I went into a hot flash. I used to be the kind of person that never got visibly upset, I kept everything inside, but the flashes gave me away. I got so hot I radiated heat and my husband could tell immediately that I was flashing. Part of the rage and screaming you are feeling is normal for post breast cancer (or other similiar conditions). It is a sort of depression but instead of feeling down, you feel angry, terribly angry. Talk to you doctor about
 the Wellbutrin. I took it for awhile two different times and it didn't help me, but now a I am taking Lexapro and it seems to be working ok. All medicines are not for all people. There is a cream that one of our dear sisters used to talk about
 several years back to help with the vag dryness. Maybe someone can tell you more about
 it. Astroglide I think was the name. Unless it was a joke, but I don't think so. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Any help available for menopausal symptoms?

Posts.Content:
Hi Claire, I'm sorry I kinda missed responding to you earlier. What wonderful news about
 your new daughter on the way. I have a great grand daughter living only three miles from me who is now almost 4 months old. She is a joy. My grand daughter called me today while she was bathing her so I could hear her laughing and splashing. She was really having a good time!! I guess I need to get over there and watch a bath soon. Don't worry about
 your age, just enjoy those girls!!!!! 
I love the "bum bag" name. I think that is cuter than a fanny pack. One of my favorite stories is telling about
 a woman who was at the doctor's office with her drains carried on a little pillow. It was hilarious!
I hope your aunt does well with the surgery. She has a rough load with a husband so ill as it is. I'm sure you will be of great comfort to her.
Hugs across the pond, MK

Posts.Title: Looking for some help for aunt about to have mastectomy and node removal....

Posts.Content: QB has given you good advice. There are many reasons for a soreness. Get to a doctor as soon as you are able but don't panic if it is not for a few weeks. Unless there are signs of infection (redness and warmth) you can wait a little while for an appointment. If it looks like an infection, you do need to get on antibiotics so be sure to tell them when you call for an appointment. Let us know what you find out. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Nervous about my soreness in left breast

Posts.Content: I am really late and as usual procrastinating. Hope you had a great birthday. Whenever you want to play Lit just let me know. I'll sing Happy Birthday to you as we play. LOL Love MK
Posts.Title: Happy Birthday, Libby!

She made a great score on her boards taken in June which will help her in getting a choice of residency. They grow up, Annette. Before you know it, that little princess will be graduating from junior high and then high school. I know how much you appreciate, love and cherish her!!!! Give her a hug from me, too. MK

We need rain so badly in north Texas and they are getting it by the bucket fulls in the area where Rita hit last year. Houston is also getting like 3" per hour. Posts.Title: Rita/One Year Later

Posts.Content: LOL What a good way to start the day, reading a post by Joyce explaining our fun and imagination! Remember several of us got instruments in Louisville. Mine was the tambourine, now if I could just fit in the aisles of the plane I could play as we fly. We all need a little fun in our lives! Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Trying to explain PCE

Posts.Content: Go for a biopsy!!!! That is the only way to know for sure what you are dealing with. Being worried for months until another mammogram is not something you want to do. Most of us don't have a history of breast cancer in the family. AND a lump does not automatically mean breast cancer, but if you should have it the sooner you find out the better chance of an easier trip through the journey. I had two benign lumps long before my diagnosis nearly ten years ago. It was caught early and I have not had any cancer issues since. Be proactive and look out for number one. We are here to help with any questions any time. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: scared

Posts.Content: I think bilateral is the way to go, too. I had rt side mast, had reconstruction done and I think I would have rather done the bilateral and gone au naturel......... but if you want to dress up you can always wear prosthesis. When you don't a T shirt and braless is great. There is all kinds of experience here to help you along the way. Hugs MK
Posts.Title: Another biopsy

Posts.Content:
Sorry I didn't read it because Peter had been here and cleaned up another post so I figured he had checked it out and it was ok. I'll check it now. And I agree with you, I would love to see all those lovely bald heads and a couple more. Leah comes to mind from the Louisville trip. How beautiful she was bald. Recently Jenn's family sent out some great pictures of her in Memory of her death a year ago. She was gorgeous, too. So sad. 
Maybe we were in a full moon? Seems that brings out the strangest beings or as you say Halloween is getting closer.

Posts.Title: there seems to be a rash that's going around...

Posts.Content:
I have had shingles a couple of times, but luckily have never had the really bad pain associated with it. After I learned what it looked like I called the dr immediately and got the medication that works when you catch it early. As Lauri said, I read in the paper about
 the vaccine, too. I guess we are prone to having shingles because the immune system is weaker after having had cancer, treatments, etc. Hope it is much better now. Hugs and love, MK
Posts.Title: Geez, now what??

Posts.Content: Several weeks ago I went to a sleep clinic, sent by my PC because I told her I was soooo tired all the time.  I was just sure that sleeping problems was not the cause, but she insisted.  So I went, was hooked up to all kinds of wires and sensors and believe it or not I actually went to sleep that way.  When I woke in the morning I felt like things had gone very well.  I seemed to have slept well.  HMMMMM A few days later I went to see the results.  They showed me graphs of my night's sleep.  Let me listen to myself snoring..... that was lovely.  Then they began to explain what the graphs indicated.  It seems as though I stopped breathing 200 times during the night due to sleep apnea.  The longest time I held my breath was 37 seconds. Now I couldn't do that if my life depended on it awake. So back I go again tonight, this time I will be fitted with a machine that sends air through my nose and all those wires and sensors will be hooked up again.  Oh Joy.  What fun old age is getting to be.  Hugs MK
Posts.Title: I'm going to a sleep over tonight..............

I am sorry for your loss of a good friend, I know it is not an easy time to go through. Prayers for her friends and family, MK

Posts.Title: Thanks for flying PCE!

Posts.Content:
You go girl! Beat those drums! Play those horns! There's a celebration going on around here for Jackie!!!! Wow and double Wow, what great news. I remember all that you have been though over the years. Let's keep the records clean.
Remember several years ago when we met at the Grapevine Mall Rain Forest Restaurant? You brought your kids and I brought my grandkids? There was a little blonde headed guy with me who started taking trombone lessons in 6th grade band. It turns out he got all the right genes from all sides! He is so good on that trombone that his judge for solo contest told him "Bravo" you will play with a symphony some day. We just learned in the past few weeks that he has been chosen to play with the Fort Worth Youth Symphony, one of the youngest at 14 to ever earn that privilege. Next year they are going to China! I took him at Christmas to buy him a special mouthpiece he wanted and even the guys at the music store told me how good he is just listening to him trying mouthpieces. His Junior High Band director loves him.
Big hugs, MK
Posts.Title: Miracles do happen!!!

Posts.Content:
Thanks again for the update, Joyce. It sounds as though Cathi has her usual positive attitude. I can't imagine what 100 staples would be like. My grandson had about
 20 when he had the osteochondroma removed from his leg and it looked like a long incision. I am sure everyone will be thinking of Cathi during power prayer Sunday tomorrow and it will give her some comfort to know she is so loved. Hugs, MK

Posts.Title: Cathi update!

Posts.Content: Hi Eve, There are several members here who have had bilateral mastectomies, a few who had ovaries removed and some of know they carry the gene.
